DIV1.P: THE FORCE OF CALUMNY: A PLAY, IN FIVE ACTS.
TRANSLATED FROM THE GERMAN OF KOTZEBUE.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED FOR C. SMITH AND S. STEPHENS BY JOHN FURMAN. 1800

NOTE.P: Syndicus, is the title of an officer in the Law Department in some parts of Germany.

LIST.ITEM: EDWARD SMITH, an Englishman, his Clerk.
COUNT SCHARFENECK, Prime to the Prince.
YOUNG SCHARFENECK, his Nephew, a Gentleman of the Privy-Chamber.
ALLBRAND, Private Secretary to the Prime Minister.
PILZ, an Officer of the Police.
THOMAS, an old Servant to Morland.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A Room in MORLAND's House. The Brst-Table set out.
EMILIA enters at a side-door, and speaks as she enters to some∣body behind the Scenes.

SP.SPEAKER: EMILIA.
SP.P:
GO to bed, Catharine, I you! (Coming forwards) The poor old woman must be very cold!—'Tis well that these nocturnal walks will soon be at an end!—I have indeed promised poor Ellfield to see him again to-night, and I dare not go alone. Yet why not?—What need I fear in so short a distance?—What accident can happen to me?—Well, well, in a few days all will be revealed▪ Mrs. Ellfield recovers fast, and by Mor∣land's birth-day I hope will be in perfect health.—What pleasure shall I feel in presenting these unfortunate people to him upon that joyful occasion, and saying, Dear husband I have preserved the lives of a worthy pair by the savings of my frugality; I have rescued the husband from want, the wife from sickness,—accept this offering as a birth-day tribute! — And must the story be disclosed?—ah, I feel that the enjoyment of a good action is annihilated the moment that action becomes known: if another praise thee,—there is an end of thy reward;
but is thy own heart thy sole confidant,—new transport always arises from the recollection!—Morland, therefore, shall know all. Ah, could he foresee that a still more important discovery awaits him!—Thanks to Heaven! I can no longer doubt of the joyful event!—but this happy communication shall also be deferred till his birth day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Good-morrow, sister!—of what happy communication were you talking to yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: That you have a fine br of young goslings hatched this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Sarcastic girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Or have you spun up all your flax?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Any one who heard you, would suppose, that my at∣tention was solely occupied by geese and spinning▪

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Your happiness is so eat, that you cannot have more important objects of sode.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Do you suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny
SP.P: Can I never hear the story often enough?—Evening after evening do I sit with you, my brother begins to read, my sister to work; but scarcely has the one read a half dozen sen∣tences, or the other set in half a dozen stitches, before a dead stop is made; and the blank in the narrative filled up with a long parenthesis of caresses, and "my dears," and "my loves," till I am tired of the repetition.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Do you not recollect, that Gethe says, to behold two real lovers, is a scene to charm even the gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And, do not you recollect, that Musaeus says, It may be a scene to delight the gods, but to mortals it is ennuyan in the extreme.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I confess it a scene, in which one would rather be a performer than a spectator.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The one sighs, "Ah, sister I am so happy!"— "Bro∣ther I have heard that about a thousand times." The other lisps, "Jenny, my happiness is unbounded!"—Sister, I know all your fine rhapsodies by heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Why do you not seek like happiness?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: There, again!—dear sister, you know as well as I, that a maiden must not seek, she must only find;—and, good heavens! how rarely can we find what we are not permitted to seek!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Whoever would gather a flower, must at least stretch out a hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The roses of lo ow only in summer,—the thorns of wedlock last the whole year round.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Does that reflection arise from observations made in this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Heaven od!—No, a perpetual spring reigns here, as in Mahomet's padise.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: And in every place love is combined with a taste for domestic life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: But amid this prating, we have wandered from our text. I wanted to know the subject of your communication?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia
SP.P: Have you never, in the midst of all our happiness, heard us name one single subject of regret?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Of regret.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: And unite in an ardent wish, that heaven would con∣secrate our union by a still longer pledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Most poetically expressed!—But am I indeed to un∣derstand that you are likely to become a mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Undoubtedly!—Yet, be silent, dear Jenny!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And my brother is still ignorant of this joyful news?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I feared to deceive you all by illusive hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Knocking at the door of Morland's, study) —Brother, come hither directly! important tidings await you! leave your writing! that may be deferred till another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Be silent, I entreat!—I wish the communication to be reserved for his birth-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Can joy be too soon imparted? (she opens Morland's door) Henry, will you not come?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Dear Jenny!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Well, here I am!—Good-morrow, dearest Emilia!— and now, Jenny, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The matter!—only that I am afraid poor Pompey is likely soon to be wholly superseded in your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Truly, an important bject, on which to call me from my writing. But whence this ear?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Because we seldom lavish our affection upon brute animals, but from the want of more interesting objects.—Have you not often made this remark yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What?—how!—Jenny!—E!—Come, come, this is too serious a subject for trifling! (he looks alternately at his wife and sister) Emilia, believe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Yes, dearest Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (after clasping her in his arms for a while in silent extasy) God! I thank thee that thou hast listened to my most ardent wish!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I meant this to have remained a secret till your birth∣day; but that prattler—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, Jenny, how will this news rejoice our father!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: To-morrow is post-day; I will write to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Then will the good old man drop a tear into the lake of Geneva.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Or hasten to the grave of our mother, where he will feel this transport most deeply.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: It is a long time since I wrote to him—beg him to excuse me!—you know that my business—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I make excuses for you!—by no means!—that you have, for a long time, sat in your study whole days together, and lately even slept there, that you might be up earlier in the morn∣ing to renew your labours, I well know;—But what you are about—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: You cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
Morland.
SP.P: To accomplish that restoration, I must still work. Never was it more necessary to take example from the watch∣ful crane, whose figure crowns the arms over our city gates. On one side, too much required, on the other too much refused!— The prince is diul, the people presuming, and neither party can enjoy a moment's repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny
SP.P: But with us, God be thanked, all is quiet!—Aetna sends forth torrents of fire—the earth trembles—and we calmly read the dread tidings in the news-papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: When the earth shakes in Sicily, a new island is sometimes thrown up in the sea of Iceland. Heaven be prais∣ed! we are quiet at present, and my nightly watchings will, I hope, contribute towards increasing our security. It is no light task, to search the archives of a town for a succession of six cen∣turies, to separate rights from customs, and claims from laws, and then to compress the result into such a form that the Prince may know enough, without the people knowing too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Will not your talk be soon finished? We have en∣joyed so little of your company for a month past—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: This very day I shall transcribe the last sheet.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Away then! write hard, and do not let us see you any more till you can throw aside that countenance of thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: This happy news has so distracted my attention, that I know not, whether I shall be able any longer to form a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Or at every word you write, some apostrophe to the future heir of your family will be intruding itself, and whenever the letter P occurs, "he says Papa," will be ready to follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Give as free scope to your wit as you please, my good sister; but unless I am much mistaken, the aunt feels no small degree of happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: She does not deny the charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Well, go to breakfast, my dears—I will be with you presently. (Exit into his Study)

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: What an excellent man!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Not one of the worst of hum ngs, indeed! a true honest Swiss!—his anceors fought at Morgarten.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: How happy is it for me that I obeyed the dictates of my reason, instead of yielding to the ambitious views of my aunt, with her numerous line of ancestors?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: 'Tis happy, indeed, since all has fallen out so well! yet I must own, dear sister, that I was strongly averse to this match; as it did not, in my opinion, wear an auspicious aspect.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Had you fully known the principles that decided my resolution—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I had earnestly wished the union!—I had shewn that I was not insensible to the value of a woman whose innocence was so lightly estimated by a base aunt, yet who had virtue enough to prefer becoming the wife of a worthy citizen, to being the mistress of a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Silence!—not so loud!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P:
But then, indeed, my expectations would have been
raised to such a pitch, that I should not, as now, have seen you, for two years soaring so far above them.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: This testimony, dearest sister, is my pride, and my joy; and, believe me, I would, this day, do from enthusiastic af∣fection, what was then only the result of reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Singular enough for a woman to fall in love with her own husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Not singular surely;—and is it not far better than to idolize the lover at the expence of the husband? I would seriously advise you, Jenny, to follow my example, not to wait for the witchery of love, but to be content with reason and friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Again casting a reflection upon my respectable spinster state? any one would suppose me as much surrounded with suit∣ors, as formerly the rich princess of Burgundy.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: There is the gentleman of the Privy-Chamber—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: A Sp zephyr, that plays with every flower—a blighting insect that destroys every leaf he comes near. His tongue levels with the dust every respectable name, as the scythe mows down every blade of grass. I lately, however, very coolly and drily, told him such plain truths, that his hopes must now be entirely at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I know not whether you may have observed the new enemy that seems advancing to the siege from another quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: That our clerk—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The Englishman? you dream!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Women are seldom mistaken in such conjectures.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: A true English caprice! and moreover—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I know what you would say—a clerk—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Not so. A clerk wears a coat, to the button-hole of which chance may, some time or other, fasten an order.— But—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: He has a good understanding, well cultivated—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: But, nothing wherewith to make the pot boil.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I am not so certain of that—I suspect him to be richer than he appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Do not laugh, and I will tell you a truly feminine observation I have made. He wears very fine linen.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: To which I can add another equally curious. Not long since a man came to this town, who gives himself out as an English master of languages. Smith calls him his friend and fellow countryman. But I, one day saw them together upon the stairs, when Smith had his hat on, and the other, with his in his hand was bowing to him very respectfully. This struck me, and I stopped to observe them; but they immediately perceived me, appeared embarrassed, and the tone of equality was instantly resumed, though evidently with some degree of restraint; soon after which they shook hands and parted.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: What if this clerk should be a Prince in disguise?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny
SP.P: An Arcadian shepherd come to assist me in tending my flocks?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: He is certainly no ordinary man.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: So my brother says.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Secretary Allbrand to wait upon you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The odious wretch! I will not see him. (She runs out through a side door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Alas! must I be obliged to receive him? Shew him up Thomas. (Exit Thomas) Oh God! how often in this wrld are we compelled to stoop to dissimulation!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Pardon, Madam, my troubling you thus early.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: You are my husband's friend. A friend cannot come unseasonably.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Would to heaven that this were spoken as from yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Morland is not yet at leisure; will you condescend to loose a few minutes with a female?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You are sportive, Madam. You know but too well what a gain I consider this loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Possibly your business may be urgent? I will call my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Urgent! Ah Madam, I have no business so urgent as to tell you, that in your presence every thing else is forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: The air of the court has infected you.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It has only emboldened me to declare my feelings.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (Embarrassed, and endeavoring to turn the conversa∣tion) I understand that a new play is to come out at the thea∣tre this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: At which I would indulge a hope that you may be present.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: 'Tis possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Then I may look forward to spending some hours of transport.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Of that you scarcely can fail, since the piece is Schroeder's.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The theatre is the only place where I may be al∣lowed to contemplate those charms, without offending your ri∣gid notions. There leaning against a pillar, alone in the midst of a surrounding croud, my eyes remain immovably fixed upon your box;—you see me not, while I see only you;—some∣times, indeed, your fan or muff are alone to be seen;—but even to behold them is soothing to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Secretary Allbrand, you forget your engagement.— Solely on the condition, that in future I should hear no more such language, did I consent to conceal from my husband, whom you call your friend, a passion, which to view in the most favor∣able light, is the height of imprudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Could a mind like yours harbor the idea of sow∣ing the seeds of discord between two friends, who so long since, even as youths at the university, swore eternal fidelity to each other?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Have you observed your oath?

SP.SPEAKER: Abllrana.
SP.P: Can it be perjury towards friendship to admire what my friend has found so lovely? to adore the being who makes him happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Think as you please, in silence; b never forget that the wife of Morland can only admit your friendship and esteem; but will steadily reject all pretensions to your admiration or love.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Happy Morland! yet at least permit me to com∣plain of the injustice of fate; that I who have never loved but once in my life, whose constancy might be entitled to some re∣compence, am compelled in silence to cherish a hopeless passion; while he, who, for years, only roved from flower to flower, is re∣paid by an ardor and steadiness of attachment which such levity ill deserves;—that I, to whom innocence was ever sacred, am now scorned, rejected, while he, who at Strasburgh—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: No more!—I will not hear you!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Far be from me the malignant wish to derogate from the merits of my worthy friend! particularly to injure him in the esteem of one in whom his whole happiness is centered! If at the time I reproved him severely for deceiving an innocent girl with false promises—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: 'Tis false!—Morland never deceived any one!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
I do not mention this lapse, as a thing wholly un∣pardonable. He was young—a perfect Adonis among the wo∣men,—was
it surprising that such admiration should make him vain? and we all know to what lengths vanity will a man; perhaps the want of opportunity alone, protected me from doing the like. But, what excites my indignation is, that partial fate should give him a reward due only to the purity of a first passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Secretary Allbrand, even if this story, in the dis∣closure of which you seem to find so much gratification, were true, why relate it to me? how does it concern me? what purpose do you hope to make it answer to yourself? For two years, I have been united to Morland; he has studied incessantly to promote my happiness; I have no wish unsatisfied; and what passed prior to our union, is indifferent to me; If my husband was once wild, I esteem myself the more fortunate that such courses are now entirely abandoned by him. Above all things, I de∣test the malignity that would trace back the life of a man even to his cradle, to enumerate how many times in his childhood his mother was constrained to use the rod. In short, Sir, I will hear no more! To preserve domestic harmony, and spare my husband some hours of painful chagrin, I have hitherto been silent; but be assured, the next time that a similar expression shall escape your lips, all shall be revealed, whatever may be the conse∣quence.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: If you suppose that an unhappy passion is to be repressed by menaces, you know little of the human heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: To deal with you sincerly, Mr. Secretary, I consider you as ready to grant any passion free ingress into your heart; but I believe none will ever gain a permanent establishment there.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I know not in what way to answer such a compliment.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Do with my compliment, as I have always done with your's—given them to the wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (with suppressed irritation) Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (as he enters) I heard right then!—I thought I re∣cognized your voice; (he gives him his hand) whether upon bu∣siness, or as a friend, most welcome!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I come in both relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I will not interrupt you, gentlemen. (Exit)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Sit down, my friend!—Have you breakfasted?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Two hours ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I wited till I had finished my business—I thought that breakfast would then have a better relish.—Has the minister asked—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I came hither upon that account. He expects to see you to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: He shall not be disappointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The abstract—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Is ready; and I have exceeded in it beyond my hopes. I have endeavoured to be as clear, as a work of such important public utility demands.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The minister expects implicit submission.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Say rather temperate truths; and then his expecta∣tions will not be deceived.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Indeed, in taking such ground, you will oppose many courtly ideas. But so much the better;—only be upon your guard; and should he, in consequence, receive you with a haughty coldness, do not shew any resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I never swerve from the strict line of my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He is no friend to the rights of citizens.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: They are clearly defined.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yet I fear, that a decision—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Who can withstand that power?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But I know the mind of a courtier;—only oppose manly steadiness to his ipse dixit.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I say no more than may be said with propriety by a subject, and what I am bound to say as advocate for the citizens.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (with a secret malicious joy) So much the better!— But indeed the minister has very contracted ideas of what a man ought to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The citizens have not reposed their confidence in me, that I should fashion my ideas after those of the minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: There I recognize the true Swiss manliness.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Honesty is at home every where.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (rubbing his hands) I am delighted with the idea of this audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I cannot say that I feel any delight; but I go to it, with perfect composure. The minister would have a hard task indeed to ruffle my temper to-day; for I am so tuned to hap∣piness!—Dear Allbrand, participate my transports;—I am likely to become a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (starting) Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What, for two years, I have ardently wished, but had almost ceased to hope, is at length granted me. God be thanked for so great a blessing!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (in a constrained manner) You give me a most un∣expected pleasure!—Believe me, I take the warmest interest—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Without many words—friendship is not wordy.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It is but right, that Emilia should pay you in one way what she deprives you of in another.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What she deprives me of!—I do not understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I mean that you are an object of hatred to the cour∣tiers. You know the old Latin saying, "regis ad exemplum totus componitur orbis."

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Because she gave her hand to a citizen.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Not so.—That was the subject of their sneers and arcasms for three days; and then was wholly forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: My God!—you know very well—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What do I know?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The Prince is young and vain;—he will never par∣don you for having superseded him.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Why that question?—as if I told you something new.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: New indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You cannot be ignorant, that the prince was formerly a suitor of Emilia's.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The prince a suitor of Emilia's?—What am I to understand by this insinuation?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: What is commonly understood, when we talk of a Prince's being a suitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Allbrand, I consider this as an affront.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Good God! how can you consider it as an affront, to hear from the mouth of a friend, what has long served as an amusement for all the gossips in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: That the Prince had made proposals to Emilia?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Very brilliant proposals, and very urgently offered.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And Emilia?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Did what honour and virtue required of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: She never mentioned a word of this to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I am astonished at that.
It was known to all the gossips in town, yet was to be concealed from me!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Doubtless to avoid giving you uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I am made more uneasy by hearing it thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I am not surprised at that, and, viewed in this light, Emilia has certainly been wrong in the secrecy she has observed. She ought to have told you the story herself, lest it might perchance reach your ears from some other quarter, when it would be served up, adorned with all the pretty circumstances, with which rumour delights to garnish such dishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And are such stories indeed whispered about?— Such stories of my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Abllrand.
SP.P: Heavens! can you be astonished at that? You know the world,—know how much it is the aim of every scoun∣drel to run down all merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But the particulars of this history?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Why, what would you—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I require them as an act of friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Then I must obey. It is said that your wife—but, pray, excuse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: No, no—say on! they will make no kind of im∣pression upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It is said, that your wife and the Prince were once upon very good terms—extremely good terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What mean you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It is no wonder if the Prince's fine person and ami∣able qualities should, at the first moment, dazzel the immagina∣tion of a young girl; but the rest, I have no doubt, are malicious additions.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Most certainly!—yet that people should dare to say such things of Morland's wife.—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The affair is very little talked of, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But still sometimes hinted at?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Must I remind a man who knows the world so well, that a good action is often forgotten in twenty-four hours, while a tale of calumny is scarcely ever wholly laid asleep, even when its victim rests in the grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: In truth, my friend, you have found the means of embittering the happiest hour of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: For shame! Why do you suffer such a foolish business to torment you? follow my example and laugh at the tale. It was but yesterday that I absolutely laughed in the face of an old lady, who positively asserted that the intercourse between the Prince and Mrs. Morland still continued.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Still continued!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Had been maintained with intermission for four years. As if a Prince's love could last out an Olympiad! Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Mere malice!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Neither more or less.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Pitiful envy!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And no reasonable man, therefore, would gratify the babblers by suffering the affair to give him the least un∣easiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Yet I must own myself hurt at Emilia's never men∣tioning the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It astonishes me. But the more virtuous the wo∣man, the less does she like talking of such conquests.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: She had doubtless sufficient reasons for her silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Emilia could not act but upon sufficient reasons.— But, it grows late— (He rises) Farwell, my friend—we shall meet again at the minister's.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Rising) That four years ago the Prince had inten∣tions?—You know this for certain?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I cannot say, that I was ever present at an inter∣view;—I only give you common report.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: At an interview!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And if she did stray a few steps out of the right path; why concern yourself with an affair that happened two years before the commencement of your acquaintance with her. In a very few weeks the error was seen and relinquished—and —ah Morland!—were the women to keep to strict a reckoning with us, what husband would dare to look a wife in the face?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.P: Strange!—what hateful ideas are floating in my brain?—But it cannot be true!—and were it so; is Emilia to be condemned because she is lovely and amiable?—She is certainly guiltless!— She must be, by heaven!—Yet, she should have imparted the circumstance to me!—her concealment of it was not right!—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (Giving Morland a paper) Sir, here is the copy.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What copy?—Oh, I recollect!—You have finish∣ed it most expeditiously.—But, I forgot to tell you, that, some∣where in the paper, an erroneous quotation from Montesquieu, has crept in, which should be corrected.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I perceived, and have corrected it.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Perhaps I have been guilty of impertinence?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: On the contrary, you have conferred an obligation. —You are then acquainted with Montesquieu's works?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: He is one of my favourite authors.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: It seems very extraordinary, that a man so accom∣plished as yourself, possessing not only a perfect knowledge of your own language, but also of the French and German, and to whom many other branches of learning are familiar, should be condemned to so low a situation as that of a clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (Shrugging his shoulders) Fate—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland
SP.P: Excuse me if I cannot help saying, that I have fre∣quently suspected your birth to be above your present circum∣stances.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Then why concern yourself with my origin?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: If you are following your own caprice, it is mat∣ter of indifference to me?—but should misfortune be the cause of your degradation, were I made the confidant of your troubles, I might be enabled to procure you some amendment in your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Have none but the unfortunate, need of confidants? I am not unhappy, yet I might be much happier.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Can I assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: With the truest pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Your hand upon it? (Morland gives him his hand) Have I obtained your good opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Entirely;—nor will you ever loose it again, if you always remain what you have been for the last two months.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I am always the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I consider you as a man of abilities and integrity.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Your wishes are gratified.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Then speak without reserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I will.—I love your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Starting back) Indeed! this was not what I ex∣pected to hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And what you are not pleased at hearing?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Why do you suppose so?—if—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Let it remain between ourselves alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Rely upon that—but there are circumstances—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I am rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: That is in your favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Not much. I am a Lord also; but, that is of still less account.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: How?—explain this romance?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Does what I say appear like romance?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What is your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Sidney.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And you have assumed this extraordinary disguise?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: For your sisters' sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: To speak in plain terms;—for as you could not pos∣sibly unravel this aegnima, yourself, I must, for once, allow my∣self to say more than I usually do. In my early years I was a courtier, but the court is not my element; fortunately for me I became acquainted with John Howard, who taught me to be a man. Peace to his ashes! Many an infirmary, many a prison have we examined together; and by this intercourse my mind was gradually strengthened and enlightened. When he quitted England for the laudable purpose of extending his benevolence to the whole race of mankind, I attached myself to his compa∣ny. With him I have explored the interior of Africa, and visit∣ed Abyssinia, though not, like Bruce, drank to the health of a Prince whose dominions lay somewhere about the source of the Nile. My concern was rather with the sources of good and ill in the heart of man—the sources whence might flow happiness in life, and composure in death.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And you have succeeded?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Thus much I have ascertained—That under the palm-tree of Negroland, as under the oak of Germany, domestic peace, and domestic comforts, are, if not the only, at least the prime sources, of mortal happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Smiling) And were you obliged to explore the interior of Africa to ascertain that?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: What lies direclly before our eyes, is often sought at the greatest distance. Every spreading tree that we behold, in∣vites us to enjoy peace and serenity beneath its shade; but we pass it by, and only hope to taste repose beyond the grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And the experience you have collected in your travels, you wish to reduce into practice?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You are right. This has long been my wish, and at length I hope the object is attainable. For four years past, I have been in search of a good wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: So long, and not yet found one? your researches must have been conducted very negligently; many good wives are to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: 'Tis possible,—but I have seen so much of the world, that I have become suspicious—this is the worst effect of ex∣perience. My feelings are like those of a connesseur in paint∣ing, who, amid a magnificent groupe of figures, should pass over the most prominent with contempt, and gaze with delight and astonishment at one, which to the eyes of common observers, appeared lost in the superior grandeur of the rest. Believe me, Mr. Morland, it is a true, but melancholly observation, that our sensibilities to the joys of life, evaporate as the transient dew-drops upon the rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Then, a prudent man should endeavor the more ar∣dently to cherish them, while a last fleeting drop still remains.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Such is my determination. My pilgrimage is at an end; I am arrived at my goal.—Jenny has won my whole soul, she is the single drop I wish to cherish. Her form is lovely— her mind far superior—her understanding is cultivated, while her heart remains true to nature;—She is charitable and benevolent, without knowing it—witty, without intending it. She never concerns herself with the affairs of others, nor scans the fashion of her neighbor's new gown or cap, to turn them into ridicule. She endeavours to exculpate all who are guilty only of weaknes∣ses, and never condemns in severe terms even the most palpable criminality. Above all things, she possesses that richest of all treasures, an equanimity of temper which is the same yesterday, to-day, to-morrow, and forever. Oh! what an infinite source of happiness is idcluded in that one quality!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Smiling) How came you so intimately acquainted with this phoenix?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: First at the theatre.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I did not know that you had ever accompanied her into our box.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I was not in your box—I was in the pit.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: An opera-glass acquantance then?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Nor can there be a better medium for forming an ac∣quaintance; provided the mind will use it,—nor merely the eye. I will venture to assest, that a tolerably accurate opinion may always be formed of a woman, only by attentively observing her behaviour at the theatre.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Truly visionary.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I mean, supposing the piece to be such as affords suffici∣ent ground for observation. For instance, if a woman be looking around at the company, when Philip is engaged in conversation with Posa, I can immediately measure the extent of her under∣standing. If at the lamentations of the mother in Iffland's Forest∣ers, or at the story of Just's spaniel,—a woman's eyes remain dry; it gives me an immediate insight into her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And Jenny was accidentally so fortunate—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
Accidentally!—Jenny, was still Jenny. She never came to see and be seen, but always sat in the corner of her box absorbed in attention to the piece. Her smiles and tears were not ostentatiously displayed, but lost in her muff; she never clapped, but appeared uneasy when any fine passage was interrupt∣ed by the clapping of others. This made me observant—I conti∣nued my observations for some months—I found that these were not the mere impulses of the moment, but the settled feelings of her heart; and I resolved to become acquainted with her.— Where, and in what manner to procure an introduction to this fair incognita, then became the question?—Should I seek to dazzle the imagination of my future wife with the prospect of rank and fortune?—No! never! never!—If the humble Edward Smith could not win her affections; I resolved that her hand should never be given to the rich Lord Sidney. I heard that you were in want of a clerk; I offered my services,—my plan suc∣ceeded—they were accepted. Under this disguise I have for two
months secretly watched every thought, every action, of the be∣loved object—I have observed her, under circumstances when even the slightest veil that conceals the feelings of the soul, is thrown aside; and my reason is now satisfied;—it has permitted my heart to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Does my sister know this?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!—You are her brother, a man of sense and discernment, and stand in the place of her father—have you any thing to say against it?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: My lord, how can I—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Pshaw!—Has a single word escaped me that might be supposed to come from the mouth of a lord?—To go farther, I will also own, that I have no less accurately observed you—I am convinced you are an honest man;—I as little throw away my friendship lightly, as my love. Will you be my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: With my whole heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Enough!—Give me your hand!—no more at present, and let what has passed, remain a profound secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But I cannot possibly retain you any longer as my clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I request it as a favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The women will observe my embarrassment.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Why should you be embarrassed?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Jenny is a nice observer.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Most certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And a man-hater.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I rejoice to hear it. A reconciled enemy is always the warmest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: When will you declare yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I know not.—When courage and opportunity suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: A man who has traversed Abyssinia cannot want courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A fool alone has courage in love—the Abyssinians have as little courage in this respect as ourselves. Have you farther employment for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I must go now to the Minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: In the afternoon I will bring you documents to prove my rank and fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I can trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: That would be folly. I may be an adventurer, and deceive you through impudence—never trust any one. (Exit.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV3.STAGE: —MORLAND alone. He makes a long pause, looking after SMITH.
DIV3.P: Never trust any one!—not even a wife!—Alas! is this all that can be learnt by travelling the world over—that no man is to be trusted!—better be sometimes deceived, than live in con∣stant suspicion!—I cannot do that—my heart revolts against it! —Emilia, it is well that the Briton has somewhat dissipated my thoughts!—yet they will recur to one fatal subject—Oh All∣brand! Allbrand! thou hast placed a worm in my bosom which gnaws my very vitals!—Shall I, without reserve, impart all my torments to Emilia?—that perhaps were best!—A husband or wife cannot guard too cautiously against suffering aught to smo∣ther within their bosoms, that may at least burst forth into an unquenchable flame. Yet, to-day, I never can assume sufficient fortitude to mention the subject—at least not now—in the even∣ing, perhaps, when all business is over, and the twilight of do∣mestic peace may succeed a day of storms—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (throwing her arm affectionately round him) Are you at last alone, dearest Morland?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (withdrawing himself from her in confusion) Yes— I am alone—and—I wish to be alone!— (Exit into his study.)

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (overpowered with astonishment) What can this mean!— (she sta fixed in thought) My God! what can this mean!!!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: —The Minister's Audience Chamber. Young SCHAR∣FENECK Sitting and Playing caressly with his Snuff-Box, Ring, and Watch-Chain. PRUNK standing by him. Captain ELL∣FIELD leaning against a pillar at a little distance.

SP.SPEAKER: SCHARFENECK
SP.P: FOR God's sake, talk, Prunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: What can I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: His Excellency has an assembly and card-party, this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I know that already.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: His Excellency does not dine at home to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I know that too.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: I don't know what to say, then—you know every thing beforehand.—To-day is Monday,

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—Prunk, can you guess why I laugh?—'Tis because you really at last have told me news; for the devil fetch me, if ever I know either the day of the week, or the day of the month.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Except you should chance to write a draft.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Bravo!—well said, Prunk!—you come on—the idea was not bad,—Come, again—

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: I am quite exhausted.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What?—served so long in the anti-chamber, and not yet learned to talk a great deal about nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: My duty is to say nothing about a great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You play very prettily with an antithesis. But, seriously, have you much to keep yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: At least, frequenting the court, has taught me to appear as if I had.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You certainly have talents.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: That is my misfortune; else I had not remained so long, only valet of the Privy-Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Shcarfeneck.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Great people love to consider themselves as creators· Now a clever fellow is something ready formed to their hands, and no creation of theirs; a stupid fellow, on the contrary, is a mere block; and if a Prince form him into a Privy-Counsellor the manufacture is all his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You think the stupidest fellows, rise the most rapidly?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: They do not rise, they are pushed up.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And by whom? by the women. Believe, me Prunk, Court favor is commonly the effect of female caprice.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: That cannot be, when your honor has never risen beyond gentleman of the Privy-Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: My own fault. Could I have cringed to the ugly painted creatures about the court I might have been Chamber∣lain long ago. But my devotion to the fair sex, has never been a matter of interest—if I see a lovely Madona countenance, I never concern myself with enquiring whether she be a fag-end of quality or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (With a significant wink) Miss Jenny Morland for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You mistake—I am quite off with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Off! again?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: The girl can find no place in the creation good enough for her little pert turned-up nose. She would fain have seduced me into committing the greatest folly of which a man can be guilty, matrimony—or, possibly her prudery was only in∣tended as a varnish to conceal the blemishes of her former in∣trigues.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Intrigues! she has always been considered as ex∣tremely modest and reserved.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Modest! But remember we are not alone.— (Makes a sign towards Ellfield, and then speaks in a half whis∣per to Prunk) Prunk, who is that statue up in the corner?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: One captain Ellfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What does he want?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: A pension, no doubt—that's the cry of all these people.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Send him away.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: I have told him, twenty times, already, that his ex∣cellency would not be spoken with to day, but he will not stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: A truly comic figure, faith! he drags one foot like a rane, when it stands stretching out its neck upon some lofty pinacle.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He is lame from a shot in the leg.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He seems good for nothing but to be shot at.— Look at his hand crammed so stiffly into his waistcoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Prnuk.
SP.P: He has only a false arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck-
SP.P: False?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: His own arm was carried away by a cannon ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You excite my curiosity. I'll amuse myself with him for a while. (to Ellfield) Will you be seated, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Pray do not stand at that distance!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I thank you, sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: For a few civil words. If such were not to be acknowledged, the art of making acknowledgements might soon be forgotten here.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (aside) Upon my word, this fellow is not an ab∣solute fool! (to Ellfield) I am afraid my uncle will not be seen to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Then I must be content to do once more, as I have done every day for the last month.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: That was?—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Yo come again the next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Captain, you must not consider it as a particular affront to you, if amid the croud of supplicants who daily throng around my uncle, he have not always the power of dis∣tinguishing between the man of real merit and the mere pre∣tender.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Ministers are appointed for the purpose of learning those distinctions.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What have you done for your native country?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: My duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Then he will perform his.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I trust so.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You have suffered much in the service.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I am an absolute cripple.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And your dismission is the only recompence you have received?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: By which I am left without bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: It it expensive to live where the prince resides.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I am surprised at that.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Why surprised?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Because the population is so thin.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What do you mean?—this city contains fifty thousand inhabitants.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: So I have been informed.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And with truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I can scarcely believe it. I brought at least twenty recommendations from the army, to people who were said to be resident here; but, not one of them can I find; and if my visits to this house are to be continued in vain for some weeks long∣er—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You would swear through thick and thin, that my uncle did not live here?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: You are perfectly right.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—It is very obvious that the court is not your element.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Thank God, it is not!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Three things are indispensably necessary to all who would make their way there;—sound legs, a flexible back, and a smooth tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: With not one of which I am blessed.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Then you are on the high road to starvation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Both my poor sick wife, and myself, have been very near the end of our journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Married, too?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Yes▪

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Poor man!—And how did you help yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I have no power of helping myself, as you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And foreign aid must not be expected within the atmosphere you now breathe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Philanthropy is to be found, even in the purlieus of a court.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: By the help of Diogenes' lantern.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: No, there are benevolent beings who can even seek out misery, and unsolicited, afford it consolation, and assistance; —yet nobly keep their names in concealment.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Indeed!—I thought, I was tolerably well ac∣quainted with the character of every one near the court; yet I confess myself at a loss to divine who this may be?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: She will not be known.

SP.SPEAKER: Sharfeneck.
SP.P: A she too!—Oh hasten, dear Captain, to satisfy my curiosity!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I have told you all that I know myself; perhaps I have been to blame in saying so much—the bare mention of the circumstance may be a transgression against that benevolent crea∣ture's wish of secrecy. But, so few happy moments fall to my lot, that I can scarcely command myself, when I think of those she has afforded me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Humph!—a lady!—Was she young?—hand∣some?—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: An angel!—Yet I am almost ashamed of applying to to her, a term so often misused by poets and romance-writers.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And this unknown angel?—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: By accident learned our distresses, and has ever since, even at midnight, brought consolation to my garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: At midnight!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Virtues and crimes, alike, shun day-light;—the form∣er from modesty, the latter from fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I wish you joy, Captain—a cripple, I perceive, may make conquests.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: For shame, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Female virtue in the streets at midnight!—Ha! ha! ha!—I know what to think of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Fool!—why did I give vent to my feelings in such a place?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: In the great world, one soon looses all belief in exalted virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Then, for the first time, I feel my poverty a blessing!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: The MINISTER enters from his closet. SCHARFE∣NECK springs up from his seat, and bows very respectfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Good morrow, Nephew! (he looks at Ellfield, who bows—he then turns angrily to Prunk) I ordered that nobody should be admitted to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: The strange gentleman would not take a refusal.— (Prunk retires into the anti-chamber.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (approaching the Minister) For a month past I have daily sought access to your Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Ellfield, of the regiment of Braunstein.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Ellfield! of the regiment of Braunstein! right! right! I recollect your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: And your excellency will probably also recollect, that I have twice lost my baggage, and am reduced to a cripple in the service.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Bread.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Your opinions are not very consistent with our ne∣cessitous situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: My opinions can ha be known to your Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Yet—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Yet, granted they were, I should then feel the great∣er confidence in my petition's being granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: That I suppose principles of strict integrity to be the most powerful recommendation by which any petition can be enforced.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Your colonel was dissatisfied with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: My colonel! I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: You have disseminated principles—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I desirbe to be judged by my actions: my crippled limbs bear ample testimony, that I have fulfilled my duty.— Yet, I would not shrink from an investigation of my principles. May I ask your excellency of what I am accused?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Of making improper remarks upon the war.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Could my colonel be guilty of conduct so dishono∣rable as to make a private conversation the subject of an official report?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Recollect, that one indiscreet word will often do more mischief, than a thousand brave arms can repair.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: My remarks were such as might be made with the strictest propriety, among a circle of friends over a bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What reliance was to be placed upon that friend∣ship?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Experience informs me—alas! too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: You would have acted more prudently in times like the present, when all the bonds that unite society are re∣laxed, not to trust too implicitly to those of friendship. I wish you a good morning, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P:
Your excellency has at least laid down a doctrine, whence, bitter as it is, I might draw an inference that would furnish me some consolation, amid the agonies of disappointed hope; for when all other bonds are relaxed, why is that to be regarded which would force us to live? and, of what value is
life to one bowed to the earth by corporeal and mental suffering? Yes, with my one remaining arm I should certainly discharge a pistol through that head which has been the undersigned cause of my misfortune; did not an unfortunate being, who in my happier days united her fate with mine, look to me alone for so∣lace and support.—But I dare not leave a helpless wife, a prey to hunger and despair!—However reluctant I may be therefore to solicit farther; I must still entreat your excellency to grant me some trifling pension, that may preserve us from the extremity of want. Do not suppose this hat, shot through in so many places, is worn from ostentation—believe me, I have no other. My sword, and a heart glowing with love for my native country, is all the wealth fate has left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I will take some opportunity of laying your case be∣fore the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: When may I hope?—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister,
SP.P: At present, we are so overpowered with state affairs; and besides, the Prince has not, of late, been in a particularly good humour:—call again, in a few weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: In a few weeks!—Good God!—Your Excellency must surely be aware, that every hour is an age to the miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Perhaps it may be sooner—I will send for you.— (Ellfield bows and retires with slow and sorrowful steps) These people grow every day more numerous and importunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He is not so wrenched as he appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Minsiter.
SP.P: Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Not much. I only know that the poor afflicted cripple, even now occasions many a sleepless night, to many a kind-hearted lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Indeed!—Aye, it will certainly be right to keep a watchful eye over the man. He is a philosopher; and they are always a dangerous set of people—even without arms or legs.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Your Excellency's orders are obeyed; the letters are ready for signature.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And may I expect soon to receive the elucidations necessary for imposing the new duties?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland promised them to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The old book-worm has had a glorious rummage a∣mong dusty parchments.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He enters very warmly into the citizens' cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: A fanatic, who is always talking about his belov∣ed Grecians.
Let him take heed to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I have advised him to that effect. We are old friends; but the welfare of the state must supersede all private friendships.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He endeavours to instil his Swiss principles into the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It is always dangerous to trust such kind of men in any post.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Woe to him, if his influence over the citizens be misused!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He degrades the dignity of his office—talks with the meanest mechanic, as if he were his brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Cannot his wife inspire him with better notions?— She is of a genteel family.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck,
SP.P: He ridicules all such ideas—he is always yawning in the audience-chamber—and goes into the first circles with a cropped head.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I have known him for eighteen years—even from his childhood, he was rash and headstrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Enough. The Prince shall know all; he must be narrowly watched.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I tremble for my friend!—yet, were he my brother, I feel sufficient resolution to become a second Timoleon, for the sake of my country.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (enters) Syndicus Morland, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Shew him in.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What brings the good Syndicus hither?—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I hope your Excellency will find these representati∣ons on the part of the citizens to be just.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Representations!—I only required such information from various old documents, as might assist in establishing the new duties.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: It is from those old documents, that the matter con∣tained in these representations, is derived;—I have compressed it to the utmost of my power.— (Gives him a large parcel of papers.)

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Do you suppose, that the Prince will read all these sheets?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Most certainly;—for I know him to be the up∣right Father of his people.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: But uprightness cannot ensure a man against fa∣tigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: If the happiness of a nation can be purchased at the expence only of one fatigue to its ruler; it is cheaply obtained.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: That I am confident, a Prince, like ours, will not think any business fatiguing, which may ultimately promote the happiness of his subjects.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And the result of these representations?—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Is an humble hope on the part of the citizens, that the imposition of the intended duties will be relinquished.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The pretext for which hope is?—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Necessity.—Your Excellency well knows, how small is the productive, how great is the consuming trade about a court. Our inland manufactures are little encouraged; they are almost entirely superseded by the English.—A thousand ra∣pid streams flow out of this city,—one little rivulet alone flows into it. What is saved by industry, and diligence in trade, is swallowed up by duties on every thing we eat and drink, on our stock, our property—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: My God! why this enumeration?—I regret the ci∣tizens' distresses as much as you; but the necessities of the State—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I know, must be considered;—nor are the citizens insensible to the convulsion that shakes all Europe; but they know also that we inhabit a happy corner of the earth, which nature, united with the wisdom of its rulers, have preserved from these convulsions; and they hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: These are things, Mr. Syndicus, of which, those only who preside in the Cabinet, can be proper judges.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I have done my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Less of duty I desire; and more consideration for the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: He who seeks the people's happiness, manifests the greatest love for the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Insolent!—But I warn you Mr. Syndicus, that we live in times, when the banishment of turbulent spirits, is, per∣haps, one of the most sacred duties of those who guide the helm of affairs. (Exit.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: —Manent SCHARFENECK, MORLAND, and ALL∣BRAND. MORLAND shrugs his shoulders in silence, as the MINISTER goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—You, literati, are always run∣ning your heads agaist a post;—you laugh at the courtiers, and call them insignificant beings; but I would venture any wager, that a gentleman of the Privy-Chamber, in your situation would have conducted himself in a very different manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: This is always the case among people unaccus∣tomed to courtly manners. Observe the Pagods that ornament the chimney-piece in the Anti-Chamber;—the Court is the be∣nignant region, whence proceeds all genial warmth; but who∣ever would share its smiles, must nod their heads, like those Pagods, and be careful not to stand in any body's way.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: You forget that the citizens prepare the wood which enables them and their resemblances to nod.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Bravo!—Ha! ha! ha! (Takes a pinch of snuff) Apropos,—how does the lady your wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Perfectly well.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Indeed!—Perfectly well!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What do you mean by that sneer?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You know the world.—What indeed could be more natural than that a Swiss girl should wish, for some re∣freshing Alpine breezes.—But people about the Court have no idea of such natural wishes.—In short, town prattle is like a bottle of Champagne; and the purest motives are only a cork, which it throws up suddenly into the air.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What such people say or think, is to me, matter of perfect indifference.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P:
Don't plume yourself too highly upon your stoi∣cism—the hardest stone may, in time, be worn away, only by
the drippings of the rain. Trust the warning of a friend—be a little less zealous in the citizens' cause, and somewhat more at∣tentive to your domestic concerns—else it may fare with you as with Cato and Marcus Aurelius. (Exit affectedly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Allbrand, what does he mean?—am I become a com∣mon talk to the whole town?—Am I so fallen, that every fool is to jingle his cap and bells in my ears?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The coxcomb serves every body in the same way.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Let him divert himself at my expence, as much as he pleases; but by Heaven, he shall not sport with the characters of my wife and sister!—I will break the rascal's head if he dare—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Dear Morland, how many heads will you break, if—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: How!—What!—Name the carrion progeny who are so ready to caw and scratch where they suppose they have discovered a fallen deer!—I will make an example of them!— These right honorable gossips, though related to the Abyssinian monarch himself, shall—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland, Morland, you forget yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland
SP.P: No!—when my wife's virtue is called in question—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You do not recollect where we are.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I would tear the very priest from the altar, who should dare to cast aspersions on Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The Minister's displeasure has put you out of temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I thought, I heard altercation.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (to Morland) Have you any farther business with me, Mr. Syndis?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: None, please your Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: You would do well to govern your hasty temper, in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I acknowledge my fault, and intreat your pardon— there are moments when porful feeling will overcome good manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Probably, important business may await you at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: To intrude on the great, never was my failing.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Some people have strange ideas of behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Indeed the air of the audience-chamber, is not salu∣tary to the inhabitant of the Alps!—he sickens in it, both in body and mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The air of a prison is a sovereign remedy for such diseases.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Such was the opinion of the Austrian governor, four centuries ago. I am your Excellency's most humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The Austrian governors!—what does he mean?— who were those governors?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: An insolent allusion to the history of the Swiss con∣federacy.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The pedant assumes it as a certainty, that every body must be as conversant with the history of his rugged countrymen, as himself. But, what was passing here?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Your excellency is irritated; and I would by no means increase your anger. Morland is, or at least was, my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I cannot suffer my questions to be evaded. Whom does this matter concern so much as myself?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Your Excellency is undoubtedly my benefactor, my patron—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And as such I command you to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The whole affair originated in an unmeaning joke made by your excellency's nephew, which occasioned Morland immediately to cast reflections upon all nobility, calling them car∣rion progeny.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The tongue is the citizen's favourite weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And, when I admonished him gently, to consider where we were; he scoffed at the reproof, and assured me, he would not spare even the priest at the altar.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The man is ripe for destruction—a little puff of wind, and he falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Alas! my poor friend! (affects to wipe tears from his eyes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: You weep?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: So wept Brutus, when obliged to condemn his sons.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Friendship must yield to duty. Allbrand, I have great confidence in you; your admirable "Patriotic reflections" are safe in my port-folio; the prince shall see, and will doubtless reward them. In the mean time, an opportunity is presented to you, of acquiring new merit with the State; continue to main∣tain an appearance of friendship with Morland—observe him narrowly, ad every evening, impart your observations to me—it is of importance that I should know this man thoroughly.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV3.P: Be it o—you shall find, that you have not mistaken your man Morland hasten fast into the snare which he has himself afforded the means of spreading for his destruction. I could easily, at this very moment, drive him into quitting his post, even into leaving the town, but then Emilia would be the companion of his flight; and I should be no gainer; my only prospect of attain∣ing the object to which I aspire, is, by the removal of himself alone. That once accomplished—even if I cannot overcome Emilia's prudery, I shall at least be revenged upon it; and re∣venge would be enjoyment, though but of a secondary nature. But first, I must by some means procure the sketch of the "Pa∣triotic Reflections"—that must not be left in his hands, as a wit∣nes against me—then will I awaken the distrust of the citizens, and all is ever with the Syndicus.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: (peeping in) Hist! hist!—Mr. Secretary?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Well, what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Are we alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Quite alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: I have made a great discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Tell it quickly, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P:
Last night, as I was upon duty, patrolling about the streets, I saw a well dressed woman, followed by a maid, with a bundle under her arm, steal softly across the castle square.— She looked anxiously round her, several times, while I thought within myself, who can this be?—when she came to the well, she stopped and hemmed three or four times; and in a few
moments the house door, at No. 312, was opened, and she entered. I remained wandering about the square for more than an hour,—to be sure the time seemed a little tedious, but at last the door opened again, and the lady came out;—she was attended to the door by a man, of whom she took leave very kindly, promissing to visit him again the next night.— With that she tripped hastily away; and I stole softly after her, till she reached her own house.—And now, whom do you think she might be?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Some kind-hearted lady, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Mrs. Morland, as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You are mad!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Mad! Not a bit of it! I'll consent to live upon bread and water, for a month, if it was any body else. She at∣tempted to unlock the garden-door, and as it was dark put aside her veil, to find the key-hole more readily. I took the oppor∣tunity of throwing the light of my dark-lantern directly in her face, and saw her too plainly to be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And do you know whom she had been visiting?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: I fetched the constable immediately, and he says, that the house belongs to an old woman, and up in the garret lives one captain Ellfield, who I suppose was the person that let her in and attended her out.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Nay, very certain; for he is the only man in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: No, but I know that he is very poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Are you certain of the truth of this story?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Give me a box on the ear every day, for the rest of my life if I did not last night see Mrs. Morland go to visit captain Ellfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But what the devil could she want with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: That's more than I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
(In a murmur to himself) Humph! I can scarcely
suspect any thing amiss here! but no matter! it has that ap∣pearance at least; and I can make it of important use in for∣warding my plans. It may be employed as an engine for betray∣ing the husband into the commission of some rash action, and of intimidating the wife into compliance with my wishes. Yes, it is a most fortunate accident!— (To Pilz) The Captain, you say, is poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: So the constable asserts.

SP.SPEAKER: Albrand.
SP.P: Very poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: In want even of bread▪

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: So much the better!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Have you never seen him?—He has attended daily at his Excellency's, for some weeks past, to solicit a pension.

SP.SPEAKER: Albrand.
SP.P: Ha!—the same!—excellent!—conduct me to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Now?—at this instant?

SP.SPEAKER: Albrand.
SP.P: At this very instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: We have not far to go.—No. 312, in the Castle Square. (Exeunt.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: Mrs. ELLFIELD, alone, in a white morning habit, which she surveys several times.
DIV3.P:
'Tis too fine, too expensive for my present situation!—Ad∣mirable woman!—Now, I am once more out of bed, and clothed again; I could fancy myself in perfect health!—Had I a little more colour, no one would imagine that I had so lately, for ten days together, been on the very brink of the grave. My hands, my strength, are restored; I can walk and stand with∣out the assistance of a stick, or supporting myself against the wall!—thanks!—eternal thanks! to my benefactress, and my
dear Charles's love, for this restoration!—But my husband does not retutn! (She goes to the window) I dressed myself only for him—I know he will rejoice to see me thus!—but— (She draws out a broken pocket looking-glass) There was a time, when I was accustomed to a splendid toilette, with a glass in which I could see myself from head to foot!—fye! fye!— I ought not to bestow one thought upon such follies!—My Charles is still spared, and all other losses are scarcely worth a sigh!—He is a cripple, alas!—but his heart beats with equal warmth for me, as in his prosperous days; and my hands shall labour for his support!—When he was borne wounded from the field of battle, and I knelt in despair beside his almost life∣less body; had I another wish, or could I breathe another prayer, save for his recovery?—My prayers were heard!—he did recover!—and I am happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Are you at last returned, my Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: My dearest Caroline! (he observes her with looks of satisfaction.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Are you pleased to see me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (Embracing her) Let this be my answer! You surely understand it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: My heart is its interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: But have you not ventured up too soon!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: No, I feel perfectly recovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: You look pale still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I mean to take a short walk, to day—I think, the air will revive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Do not run any hazards; a relapse might cost you your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Oh, you need not fear a relapse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Remember that I cannot live without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Have you again been disappointed?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I have at length seen the Minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Indeed! Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Speak, I entreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: May heaven bless you, my Caroline!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I am blessed!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Alas! how?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: In your love!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (Taking her hand, much affected) Dearest wife! you understand making even a cripple worthy of envy.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (As he enters) I hope I do not miake the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Whom seek you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Captain Ellfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I am that person.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (Seeing Mrs. Ellfield, starts) And this lady?—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Is my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You are married then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: You seem surprised at that? May I ask with whom I have the honor of speaking?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: As a man can scarcely be allowed at a first visit to assume the name of FRIEND, I beg leave to conceal mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: This is most extraordinary!—While those on whom I e some claim for friendship forsake me, I am indebted to rangers for consolation and support.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I know your story—I consider your fate as hard— and my situation may enable me to improve it. I enjoy a con∣siderable share of the minister's favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: You will find your patronage not bestowed upon un∣grateful hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I will engage to procure you a competent pen∣sion—if—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: That if, seems to imply some condition. Is it one that I am in a station to fulfil?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Silence and confidence are all that I require.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Both which, are in the power even of a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand,
SP.P: You often receive visits from Mrs. Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Mrs. Morland!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Mrs. Morland?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I surely do not mistake?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Is Mrs. Morland, the lady to whom we are so much indebted?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: How! Do you not know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Till this moment, we only knew her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yes, she has often, at midnight—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Often, indeed! and, like an angel, has rescu∣ed me from death.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yet never told her name?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Never!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It was like herself!—Her soul is truly noble!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: It is indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Most truly so!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And she has promised this night—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: To see us again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: And enjoy the fruit of her benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Would you render this lady an essential service!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I would sacrifice my life for her!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: This encourages me to inform you, in confidence that I am so blest as to enjoy her love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: She is then unmarried?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: No, she is married, but, alas, unhappily!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Yet, if she be unhappy, to such a woman, her duty must be sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: That is the very point. Upon this subject she en∣tertains very strong prejudices.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Prejudices, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Which time would banish, could she be persuad∣ed—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Permit me to meet her at these nightly visits?— Your lodging is perfectly private—perfectly retired.—If I might see her, here, alone?—Or perhaps you would lend your assist∣ance in combating some childish notions—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (Trembling with indignation) Oh, Poverty! Po∣verty! to what humiliation dost thou reduce a man!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: (Sinking down on a chair) This is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
