SP.P: I hope you do not misunderstand me? I pledge my honour that every thing relative to the pension, shall be finished to-morrow! and do not suppose my gratitude shall be confined to that alone— (He draws out a purse) Be this an earnest—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (Enraged) Sir, I know you not,—I am ignorant of your rank and name; but whatever they may be, unless you quit my room peaceably, this instant, you shall find, that a cripple, when his honour is insulted, has strength sufficient to kick a scoundrel down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: This—to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Yes,—though you were next heir to the throne!— Begone, or I shall make use of the rights my own house gives me.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Very well, captain Ellfield—But remember that the pension is forfeited by your own indiscretion; you are your∣self alone responsible for whatever consequences may ensue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Scoundel! did he hope to make me his pimp!—me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Who can the villain be?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Some Courtier, no doubt, who judges of us by himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: We must conceal this circumstance from our benefactress.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Most certainly. Innocence, like her's, would be shocked at hearing that it was suspected capable of corruption. But I will not suffer her to go home, again, alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Charles, we have only potatoes for dinner; yet how much happier are our lots than his!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (Clasping her in his bosom) Our hearts are pure, though our fare is homely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: He would shame poverty.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: For the sake of mankind, heaven guard such villains from poverty!— (Curtain falls)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: —The MINISTER's Audience Chamber.—PRUNK, sitting and reading—Enter ALLBRAND hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: ALLBRAND.
SP.P: IS the Minister at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand,
SP.P: I must speak with him directly, upon urgent bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He will not see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He is at cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: So much the better!—Has he ill-luck?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: I believe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: So much the better again!

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: So much the worse, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Go and whisper in his ear—

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He will bid me go to the devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: My business is of the utmost importance.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: At Court, many things are very important in the morn∣ing, that become very insignificant in the evening over the card table.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I must positively—

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: You will damn your own cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: With all my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Well, if you chuse to run the hazard!— (Exit)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (alone) If he have lost, he will be so much the wore petulant and ill-tempered—his ears here, his heart at the card-table, eager to retrieve his losses. Then he will not stay long, but say at once,—"you know what had best be done, fol∣low your own judgment,"—and thus will my point be completely carried. Summon up all thy confidence, Allbrand!—chance smiles upon thee—thy good genius beckons thee forward!—How fortunate that I should meet young Scharfeneck at such a mo∣ment, and learn from him so many cirrumstances, to make my story appear the more probable!—But, Prunk returns—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: —Re-Enter PRUNK and soon after, Enter the MINISTER.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: In what sort of humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: So cross and snappish, that I have no desire to be one cf his auditors. (Exit into the anti-chamber)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Go, and welcome!—your company is not wanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (Entering) Well, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: A melancholy discovery!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Hasten to tell it, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland is a traitor!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: You have fresh proofs against him?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The most undoubted!—He holds a secret inter∣course—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: With whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: One Captain Ellfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I know the fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: They meet at dead of night—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: At the Captain's lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Are you certain of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I know from eye-witnesses that Morland steals by night to the house of this man; though by day he denies any knowledge of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Enough to create suspicion!—But what is to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: If we could catch him in the very fact—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: True!—he might be sent at once to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: His papers might also be seized.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And he himself brought to a speedy trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: If your Excellency would invest me with full pow∣ers for such a procedure—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: By all means!—but supposing his papers should prove nothing against him?—the Prince, you know, requires the utmost forbearance and circumspection in these matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The fact is beyond a doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Well, then—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: May I desire a written order? —

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (impatiently) Now, directly?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Or if your Excellency would give directions to the police-officer who waits without—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Let him come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (opens the door and calls) Pilz!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (to Pilz) I have charged my secretary with an im∣portant commission;—follow his directions implicitly. (Pilz bows obedience. The Minister addresses Allbrand) —Have you any thing else to mention?

SP.SPEAKER: Albrand.
SP.P: Nothing!—Does your Excellency recollect any further orders?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Only a strict injunction to proceed cautiously—I shall expect your report early to-morrow morning.— (Exit)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
(rubbing his hands) All succeeds admirably!— (to Pilz) Come to my apartment; there you shall receive your instructions. No; first seek the Gentleman of the Privy Cham∣ber; and say that I request to see him for a few moments—tell him of his Excellency's and Highness's commands!—away!— instantly!— (Exit Pilz.) That was an admirable thought!—
Scharfeneck shall seize and seal up the papers. The sketch of the "Patriotic Reflections" I must have!—much depends upon that!—much!—very much!— (Exit.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: —MORLAD's use. JENNY is discovered at work; SMITH standing and leaning over the back of chair at a little distance, with his eyes fixed upon her.—They remain silent, some minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: My brother is very late!—he keeps the dinner waiting a long time.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: It must be my fault, if the time appear so very te∣dious.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I do not understand how to talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: On the contrary, I have often, at table, admired your talents for conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I ought rather to be silent there and talk here.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The reverse is the most natural; since in the compa∣ny of a woman only, the subjects for conversation are so much more confined.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: But what they loose in variety, they gain in interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You have, I perceive, been so far initiated into the mys∣teries of the fashionable world, that you are an adept at making compliments.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I never make compliments,—I always speak truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (confused, after a pause) Is it long since you left En∣gland?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Many months.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And have you never, like a Swiss, experienced the mal-du-pays?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Why, then, do you not return?—A man of your talents might find employment any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Do you wish to get rid of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I cannot return, alone, to my native country.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Then why not marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: 'Tis my ardent wish!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Not that it is a step I would recommend.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Because, if you suppose all married people to be as my brother and sister, you mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I shall not easily be brought to think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Most matches are unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Of that I very much doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I can plead frequent observations of the fact, in sup∣port of my assertion. Two young people fall desperately in love with each other, and think they never can exist asunder;—a head-strong father, or a cross guardian interposes, and thwarts their wishes:—the young people sigh and pine—and pine and sigh—till at length the old people's hearts are melted. Then the lovers fancy they stand upon the highest pinnacle of fortune's temple, and clasped in each other's arms, look down with indif∣ference on every object, in the busy world around them; they rush forward into wedlock, as the night-walker to the lowest edge of the sloping roof, when suddenly some one calls, they start, they wake, and down they fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A very ingenious simile; but the position on which it is founded, is not fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P:
And there lie the poor souls, stretched in the mire of ennui, exchanging looks of discontent with each other. If, in∣deed, they be at bottom, people of sense and worth; powerful habit, after a while, will come to their assistance; till at length,
they will learn to endure each other's foibles with patience;— and each will jog on contentedly along the paved foot-path, to which his steps must be confined; thankful if no thorns spring up to obstruct and wound him as he proceeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: But if esteem be the mother of love?—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: She is, at best, no more than a step-mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Those who can reason upon love, have indeed never loved.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And are to be envied.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: To be pitied.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: An unknown happiness can have no charms.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A false axiom. Do you suppose that miners, con∣demned to grovel at an immense depth under ground, never long to behold the sun?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You have high ideas of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And still higher of wedlock. (he pushes the chair on which he leans, somewhat nearer to Jenny, but without altering his position) Love ties two beings together;—wedlock makes them only one. Love drinks down large draughts from the cup of joy;—wedlock sips up the sweets, a drop at a time; nor finish∣es them till arrived at the very brink of the grave. Love is a caterpillar, devouring dainties;—wedlock, the same caterpillar, transformed into a butterfly, when it feeds only upon the purer nourishment of the fragrance exhaled by flowers. Years roll on; but a good wife never becomes old;—winter succeeds to sum∣mer; but wedded happiness never chills. The kiss of a chaste wife, is the stamp with which nature seals her choicest blessings; —storms roar above; lightning flashes around; but where domestic love dwells, every trouble, every sorrow, is but half felt —every joy, every pleasure, is doubled.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You grow animated.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (sitting down and drawing the chair nearer to her) Woe to that man who would remain cold and insensible, while descanting on female beauty and virtue!—who would drink out of the same cup with him?—Woe to the man who pays no more respect to a good wife, than to his night gown; but because she administers daily, nay hourly, to his comfort, receives her at∣tentions without one grateful feeling; and only learns to prize domestic happiness, when lost forever!—Let thy crowns, O Chance! be scattered about like flakes of snow; I would not catch at one;—I only ask thee to bestow upon me, the simple garland of love! (he draws his chair still nearer) — Should I at length find what I have, so many years sought—find my hopes, my wishes, realized—then farewel, ye petty tyrants of the mind, ambition, thirst of fame, ardour to obtain the palm of wit!—my heart shall have no room for any guest but love. The sweet calm of domestic peace, firm union of souls, a taste for the joys of nature, love for the unempoisoned air of the coun∣try, for rural pastimes, for the pleasures of retirement, where we may live remote from envy and calumny—from—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (working very eagerly, and continually breaking her thread) Our finest dreams are seldom realized.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (drawing his chair by degrees, quite close to her) That I love, is no dream;—but that I flatter myself with my love being returned, in equal portion, may perhaps be the mere effect of a presumptuous vision. For the first time in my life, I feel my happiness dependent upon the favour of others; and, for the first time in my life, I tremble. Words are but poor interpreters of our thoughts; let this tremor vouch the truth of my feel∣ings?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Smith, whence these emotions?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
(taking her hand, eagerly) When a man feels to his inmost soul—feels so that he can scarcely speak;—when his
ice faulter—through the tears—that would force a passage— to his eyes—Oh, can his sincerity be doubted!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Smith! for heaven's sake!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This moment decides the happiness or misery of my future life!—an honest man solicits your hand—an ardent lover solicits your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The agitation that I witness, speaks in a language that cannot be mistaken—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My birth indeed is humble.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: That was not what I was going to observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My possessions are small, but sufficient to satisfy moderate wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I do not intend to sell my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Be it then the reward of honorable love!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Allow me time for consideration, dear Smith!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I thank you sincerely! (Kisses her hand with trans∣port.) What can be more grateful to an honest heart, than the asssurance that it shall be proved?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter EMILIA, leading MORLAND by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia,
SP.P: Here he is at last, but in a terribly serious humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What is the matter, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Nothing! overpowered with business.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: You have usually been, at least, cheerful at dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Because I was not oppressed with care—But do not mind me—this will pass away in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: We have expected you with great anxiety; you were always accustomed to send, when you could not dine at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Forgive me—I forgot—the minister—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: The minister? what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland,
SP.P:
(Laying his hand upon his forehead) Excuse
me—I am not well—my head aches—I feel, as if I were in∣toxicated—let me retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny,
SP.P: What can you have been about, this whole day?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Walking—no, no, only—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: First it was business, now it is walking—Oh brother! brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Forgive me!—I really know not what I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Aside to Smith) A dark shade in the picture of wedded happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: What were light without shade?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Will you go in, dearest Morland? dinner waits.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Yes!—I am ready!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Pardon me, that I come thus unexpectedly!—a very unexpected piece of business brings me hither, my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Pshaw! again business?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Go, my love—Go Jenny, sit down to dinner—we will be with you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: My dear Henry, I have provided your favorite dish.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (With constrained affection) Thanks, dearest Emi∣lia! go, depend on seeing us in a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (Aside, as she goes ot slowly, and sorrowfully) All is not right! What can have altered him thus!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Following her with Smith.) Smith! Smith! if this example cannot deter!—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No over-hasty judgement, I entreat! (Exeunt)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Allbrand, you seem disordered.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Oh, deeply,

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: New torments for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Alas!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Speak out!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: At this moment I feel, for the first time in my life, that friendship may impose upon us most painful dutie.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Truth is the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And most sacred of all duties—I fulfil it with tears in my eyes, with a bleeding heart!—Morland, are you a man? a heavy blow awts you—the more: severe as coming from a beloved hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: From my wifes?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: She is unworthy that name.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Prove her so!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: She holds nightly meetings with the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: 'Tis false!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Who has felt more implicit confidence in her vir∣tue than myself? Who has defended her more eagerly against all defamers, than myself? My heart revolted at the idea of finding her guilty of infidelity towards her husband—but

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I tell you 'tis false!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: So I asserted, as long as possibility of doubt re∣mained; but when incontrovertible facts—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Stamping eagerly on the ground) By heaven 'tis false! Come to her now, immediately—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Her tears, her denial of guilt, will be no proofs of her innocence. Would you deprive yourself of the power of ascertaining the truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And what proofs have you against her?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Emilia has, for some time past quitted your house every night.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Seizing him by the arm) Allbrand!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (Proceeding calmly) Stolen secretely across the Castle-square—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P:
(Seizing hold of him with both hands, and fixing
his eyes upon him) I ask for proofs!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Into a very notorious house.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: With his voice almost suffocated But, proofs▪ proofs!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And there met the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Seizing him by the breast) Villian! thou liest!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Any thing may be excused to a friend in your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Once more, I say, your proofs?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Will you believe your own eyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And only my eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I will remain with you until midnight: we will go together to the place; and you shall yourself be witness of her shame!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I take you at your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But unarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland
SP.P: What time is it now?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Just nine o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, God! so early!—so early!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Employ the interval in endeavoring to recollect yourself; a moment neglected never returns. Emilia's disavow∣al of the fact could not remove suspicion from your soul; and without the conviction I offer, you must lead a life of torment with a wife, whom you wish, yet dare not presume to consider, as innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I am recovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It were better not to see her again before mid∣night; should her suspicion be excited, she will not go.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I swear she will not go!

SP.SPEAKER: Albrand.
SP.P: I wish she may not.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The slanderer shall answer this calumny with his life!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: If Emilia be innocent▪

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: She is innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: At least was so once.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Come with me, look her in the face, and be asham∣ed!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Lavater cannot decide in such a case.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Name the person who has dared to calumniate her.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: She is coming. For heaven's sake do not betray yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Der Morland, you have been absent from home all day, let the evening be devoted to us!—We could not dine without you, we had no relish for a single morsel! Is not your business yet concluded?—Mr. Secretary, will you partake of our humble fare?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I beg to be excused.

SP.SPEAKER: Emllia.
SP.P: If you will not encrease our little family circle, I hope at least, you will not, by detaining my husband, contract it.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I do it reluctantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Of what nature, can be that business which robs my dear Morland of his unaccustomed serenity?—my God, Henry, how you fix your eyes upon me!—dearest husband what can thus oppress you!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Do you wish to know?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: 'Tis merely an unpleasant circumstance that has occurred in his office—nothing more.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: If it be nothing in which I can advise or assist him, yet tender participation in trouble is seldom unwelcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Do you interest yourself in my sorrows?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: My God!—what a question!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: You look at me, so affectionately!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: And you look so wildly, at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, you have not deserved it!—I know you have not!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Indeed, I have not▪

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: By heaven, I am sure of it! (He clasps her to his breast.)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You forge our business.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Your behaviour is so extraordinary!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: My heart is unchanged!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I hope so.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: As your's!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Then I will be content.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You will do better to separate. Repose cannot be enjoyed, till our business be completed. I would advise lock∣ing ourselves together into your study for to-night, and then by to-morrow's dawn, all may be finished.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: The whole night, did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Are you not pleased at it?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I fear, lest yo health should be injured!—you have slept so little for several eks!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And you wish, that I should sleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Oh, most sincerely!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Can you doubt it?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: My friend, midnight approaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Midnight!—ha!—farewell Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Shall we not see each other again, this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: You hope not?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Forgive me!—I am absent!—Come, Allbrand— good night Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Not one kiss at parting?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Morland clasps her in his arms, violently agitated) I hope it is not the last!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: God forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (Tearing himself from her) No, it is not possible! (He rushes into his study.)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (To Emilia, as he follows Morland) You will be so obliging, Madam, as to give orders that nobody interrupt us.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV3.P: Something very extraordinary must have occurred; yet he will not impart it to me!—some heavy calamity overpowers him; and he will not let me share it!—What can I have done to offend him?—Why am I, on a sudden, thought unworthy of his confidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Are you alone, dear sister?—where is my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: In his study.—Allbrand and he have business toge∣ther which will occupy them for the whole night.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You have been weeping?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Alas, yes!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Oh, I do not know!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Has my brother been unkind to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Not unkind!—Yet he is so unlike himself, that I scarcely know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What can be the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Allbrand says, that it is merely some vexation of bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: If so, you may be perfectly easy, and may rest assur∣ed that all will soon be right again.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P:
I hope so!—I do not doubt it!—yet, 'tis impossible
to describe the anxiety I feel!—I would forbear to weep, but it is not in my power!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (Half aside) This is one of the happiest unions I ever witnessed!—yet, these sorrows!—these tears!—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Think you, I would exchange these sorrows, these tears, for your boasted freedom?—No, Jenny!—Shall I have experienced unbounded happiness for two years, and now shrink at the least reverse?—Ah, it is but a momentary reverse, and these tears will soon be wiped away by the hand of love!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Dear ladies, am I to dine by myself to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yes!—for once!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Alas!—I have no appetite for dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Nor I, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And Mr. Morland?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Is occupied with business.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You seem both very uneasy—has any thing unpleasant happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Nothing at all!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I will not be intrusive. (Exit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Shall I stay and keep you company?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I had rather be alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I have no inclination myself for company.—It is true that I have much to say to you; but the present is not a propi∣tious moment for the communication. Good-night sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Good-night, dear Jenny.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Will my harpsichord disturb you?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Oh, by no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Mozart shall drive away the vapours. (Exit.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV3.P: Music will charm your mind to peace—I will endeavour to soothe mine by benevolence;—at poor Ellfield's I may perhaps forget, what occasions me so much anxiety. And shall I go a∣gain without Morland's knowledge?—better at once tell him all! —but then, the pleasure of presenting my patients to him, on his birth day, would be lost!—besides, at the present moment, it might appear obtrusive.—Hist! I thought I heard my name mentioned in the study!—Yet, what concern can my name have with business?—Shall I?—No! shame on the idea!—far be from me the meanness of listening. But now, I dare not at∣tempt speaking to my husband, since it will immediately appear as if I had listened. And why should I be so desirous of com∣municating the affair at this moment?—I shall not be missed,— and if I am, he knows me!—yet the discovery shall not be de∣layed beyond to-morrow!—all secrecy is pernicious; and I blame myself for having given way to it. I must take a short time to recover myself; and then I will go.—Heaven grant, that when I see Morland, to-morrow, he may be more composed!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter PILZ and a CORPORAL with GUARDS.

SP.SPEAKER: PILZ.
SP.P: MAKE no noise, Corporal! conceal yourself with your people; and when I give the alarm, be ready to come forth.— (The Corporal and Guards conceal themselves—Pilz draws aside the shade from his dark lantern, and looks at his watch) Wants only a quarter of twelve—we shan't have long to wait!—For my part, I don't understand this business:—the wife plays false, and the husband is to answer for it—I can't see much justice in that!—Well, well, 'tis no concern of mine; and good order must be preserved!—Hist! I hear somebody coming! (he conceals himself near the door of a house)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: —Enter SCHARFENECK, disguised in a large cloak.
DIV3.P:
It must be hereabouts!—My direction is—near the dooor of the Court Apothecary's. (he pants) How I totter under the weight of this thick heavy cloak!—or is it the adventure that makes me quake?—I cannot say, I like it much; suspect All∣brand to be over-reaching my uncle—and me into the bargain. I have no objection at all to a frolic; but an act of deliberate
villainy, goes against my conscience!—For that, however, my employers must be responsible. (he steps aside) I am to con∣ceal myself here; but should it be necessary to continue this game at hide and seek, longer than ten minutes, my patience will be exhausted; and I shall take the liberty of returning home, and going quietly to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: This is the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And that the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yes, where you see a light in the upper room.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, God! how my heart beats!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: 'Tis an awful moment to an affectionate husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The most awful that ever I experienced!— (The clock strikes twelve)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The clock strikes.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Each stroke is to me like the knell of death.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Promise me once more to command thyself?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I cannot promise any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Do not forget, that the Prince is at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: You pour oil upon the flame.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: How easily, in the midst of the confusion, might he accomplish any thing that suggested itself to his tyrannical mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh! that he would command his guards to dispa me, at the moment!—that were mercy indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Do not speak so loud!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Of what are you afraid?—Do you suppose that Emilia will hear us?—No! no!—Emilia will not come!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Heaven grant, she may not.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Then, to-morrow▪ I throw myself at her feet, and confess all!—No! this very night!—I will hasten to her bedside, awaken her gently, and, with my tears and kisses, call forth a blush into those cheeks which were never flushed by conscious guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Hark! I hear the sound of approaching footsteps.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (trembling with agitation) The steps of a female?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I should think so.—But, for God's sake be more calm!—how your teeth chatter!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh! my blood freezes. (he steps aside, trembling)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.STAGE: —EMILIA crosses the stage softly, and hems when she comes to the door of a small house. Captain ELLFIELD opens the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: We have been expecting you for some time, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: How is my good friend above?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I thank you, perfectly well. (they go into the hous, and shut the door)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Did you see?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Almighty God!—It was she herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Are you now convinced?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Scarcely, even now!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Whither will you go?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Can that be made a question? (he throws himself violently against the door of the house, into which he had seen Emilia enter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yes, break in there!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: (coming forward) Stop!—I arrest you in the Prince's name!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (thunder-struck) How!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Guards come hither! (the Guards surround Morland— Allbrand gradually draws away from him)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Do you know, who I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: The very person we seek.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: This is too much!

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Whither I am ordered to conduct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I must go into this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Don't compel me to use force!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, God of mercy! annihilate me at this moment! (he looks up towards the window where he sees the light) Infer∣nal woman, hear me!—hear me, Emilia!—be thou accursed for ever!—may some heavy judgment overtake thee, even in the arms of thy paramour!—may ye both be accursed, both thou and thy seducer!—O-h-h— (the guards drag him out; his last words and groans are heard, after he disappears)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (coming forwards again) Good heavens! how he raves!—Oh, that Pilz had but sense enough to stop his mouth!— his clamours are sufficient to alarm the whole street!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (coming from his concealment) Allbrand!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I thank you for your punctuality.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I almost repent my engagement!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: For what reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Who was the woman that stole in here?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Probably one of their associates.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Why are not the whole crew apprehended?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: All are not equally ripe for imprisonment.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What occasioned Morland to curse his wife so bitterly?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: 'Twas temporary phrenzy▪

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I wish I were in my bed!—What more is to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: We must follow the guards at a distance:—when Morland is delivered into safe custody, Pilz shall accompany you to his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: And then?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You know what—the papers—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Why not seize them yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Because I cannot be in different places at the same moment: and my presence is more necessary elsewhere. Come along, now—I will give you farther instructions by the way.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.STAGE: —A room in the State Prison. KROLL sitting at a table, with his spectacles on, reading in a large folio volume. EVE spinning, and nodding her head frequently, over-powered with sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: "Chapter the seventh,"—"How Sultan Bajazet was confined by Tamerlane in an iron cage."—It happened in the year one thousand four hundred and two, that a bloody battle"— Why, Eve! you are asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: No, no—read on—I hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: What was I reading about?

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Something or other of the lame and blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Right!—Bajazet was blind of one eye, and Tamerlane limped. But you are nodding again.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: My eye-lids will fall down.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: I can't think, where the prisoner can be!—'Tis now past midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: I cannot think who he can be?

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Neighbour Pilz was very secret; I could not get a word out of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Well, we shall know in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Truly, we shall, by virtue of our office. (a knocking is heard; Kroll lays down his book, and takes off his spectacles) Do you hear? they must be come! (he goes out with the light)

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: He has left me alone in the dark. For three whole years, have I now lived in this prison; yet never with my own good will was left so many minutes together, without a light. It has entirely scared away my drowsiness—Hark!—how every step they take, sounds through the long passages!—The great hinges of the gate, creak dismally!—the chains rattle—the gate bangs—terrible music for the poor man they are bringing amongst us!—He certainly must be some great gentleman:— for neighbour Pilz ordered the large room, with the tapestry hangings, to be prepared for him.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV3.STAGE: Re-enter KROLL with PILZ and MORLAND.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Heaven defend me, Mr. Syndicus! is it you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Merciful powers, Mr. Syndicus! who could have thought of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Come, come, neighbours; not so many words, (Mor∣land stands motionless, with his arms folded, and appears to∣tally insensible to what passes)

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Humph! Humph! I should as soon have expected the skies to fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: I am so terrified, that I cannot move a limb.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Ah? 'Tis a motely world.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: This is not motely neighbour; 'tis as black as a coal. Such a man as the Syndicus, the friend of all the poor in the town.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Who endeavoured to procure every body their rights▪

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: And always took notice of every child he met.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: But it is his Highness' command.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Well to be sure if it is his Highness—

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Who knows what lies wicked people may have told of the worthy gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Neighbour Eve, take care of your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Why to be sure, God knows the Prince is only a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: But a man favoured by God.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: That's for certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Therefore neighbour Kroll, in virtue of your office▪ here is a prisoner, for whom you are answerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Locks and bars shall answer for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: And nobody must be admitted to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Good-night, neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Good-night, Mr. Pilz. (He conducts Pilz out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: I should like to know, how the good night is to come, when he has shut an honest man up in prison?—For my part I hav'n't had any concern in it,—but what does that signify?—I know for certain, that I shan't close my eyes all night. Poor dear gentleman! how terribly he looks!—Take heart, noble Syndicus, bad weather will overtake those that are going to church as well as them that are running to the alehouse, but where the heart and conscience are warm, the clothes are soon dried.— Alack-a-day! he neither sees nor hears me!—Truly, I am only the simple wife of a poor citizen, and I don't know how to com∣fort such a learned gentleman. (Re-enter Kroll) Look there, Benjamin,—our prisoner seems to have neither life nor motion,— he stares at the door, as if he saw something.—Certainly no good will happen to us, if we dont look a little after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Syndicus, there's no occasion to take this so much at heart!—many a great gentleman has been kept up here for a long time, and yet come off with honour at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: We don't behave unkind to any body—they've com∣monly enough to bear, before they come to us; and we are glad to comfort them, if we can.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: This state prison is not an iron cage.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Ah, Benjamin! 'tis just like talking to the wind!—

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: (Takes Morland respectfully by the arm) Good Mr. Syndicus!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (starting wildly) Who are you?—Where am I? —What would you have?

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Dear heaven! don't your honour know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (examining him from head to foot with an unmean∣ing stare) I know nobody!—I know nobody!—

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: What!—has your honour forgotten—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Forgotten! (striking his hands on his forehead) No! no!—I have not forgotten—

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Would not a glass of wine be of service to you?— you shall have the best we can get.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, a whole bottle!—a whole bottle!—Yes, yes, wine, good man!—wine!—wine!—happy he who can drown his feelings in wine!—

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Leave him alone Benjamin;—he is not in his right mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Won't you please to go to rest?—Eve has prepared you a very good bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—Rest!—Ha! ha! ha!—

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: To be sure, your honour won't rest so well as at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: At home?

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Ah, God!—how will poor Madam grieve!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (going up to her hastily) Woman! do you mean to mock me?

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Oh, terrible!—to be sure, he is out of his senses!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Would to God!

DIV3.STAGE: (A knocking is heard again at the gate)

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: More knocking!—who can this be! (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Take me with you, husband!—I am afraid of being left alone with him! (Exeunt Kroll and Eve)

DIV3.STAGE: (Morland stands motionless for some moments, then clasps his hands in agony;—he feels upon his finger a ring made of Emilia's hair; he looks at it wildly, then snatches it off, and throws it away indignantly, seizes himself by the breast, and exclaims)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, that I could thus easily tear her from my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: (as he enters) If your Excellency have such an or∣der—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I take the responsibility solely upon myself!—leave us alone. (Exeunt Kroll and Eve. Allbrand approaches Mor∣land, who does not observe him: after a pause, he exclaims) Is this the reward of love and patriotism?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What voice was that!—Allbrand!—you here?— you too in prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: In the cause of friendship, I even condescended to have recourse to falshood;—I used the minister's name, and the doors were opened to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Not a prisoner, then?—But, why should you be confined?—she is not your wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Oh, my injured friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: What seek you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: To console you.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Is my house burnt down?—my whole property de∣stroyed?—A beggar might be capable of receiving consolation —but not a fond and injured husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I would give you advice, as a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Give advice to a helpless wretch plunged into a whirlpool!—perhaps throw him a straw at which to catch!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I might afford you some assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Can the ruined honour of a wife be propped up like a mouldering building?—Can faith and truth be remed▪ like an extinguished light?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: No!—but the man who has cherished a serpent in his bosom, may throw it away; and then pursue his career with renovated powers.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Even though it had struck its fangs into his heart, and the venom were poisoning the very sources of life!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Shall the infidelity of a perjured wife have power to deprive a Morland of every comfort, every satisfaction?—has not nature endowed you, my friend, with eminent talents for advancing the welfare of your fellow citizens?—Does not the noble mind often recover lost repose in seeking to promote that happiness in others, of which it is itself deprived?—May not dissipation, activity—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: In a prison?—in chains?—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Does the sun shine only upon this little spot?— Shall this soil alone experience the beneficial effects of your ardour and industry?—Will not your native country receive back with transport, into her bosom, a man she herself nourished and cherished?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, why did I ever quit so blessed a spo!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Away then, my friend; and at your pure Alpine springs drink oblivion to all your wrongs. Forget a wife who is unworthy of your love!—forget a country which repys your attachment with the basest ingratitude, but forget not a friend who loses all recollection of himself, when he urges you to this separation!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Shall innocence seek its safety in flight▪—in con∣cealment?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Was not Socrates, though guiltless, condemned?— and did he not suffer because he refused to shake off his chains.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, my friend! you cherish the wildest visions!— What means are left me for escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Be that my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Are you sensible, what you hazard?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yes, I know what hazards I run, and for whom they are incurred.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Allbrand! Allbrand! thou hast twined yet one more bond to fasten me to life!—thou hast almost reconciled me again to the human race!—yet I cannot have recourse to flight, and leave my honour a prey to all the gossips and scan∣dalous chronicles in the town. "Morland is absconded" it will be said—"On what charge was he apprehended? and why did he fly? why should he wish to escape from justice?"—Do you suppose a single mouth would be stopped by hearing, that I was guilty of no other crime than having a lovely wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Alas! no!—for the colours that are to varnish over this injustice, are already prepared.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Indeed!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You are accused of being a Jacobin.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Ha! and the proofs?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Not even your wife, as 'tis reported, could furnish any thing like proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Could not—but would have furnised them willing∣ly! (Allbrand shrugs his shoulders) Conceal nothing, Allbrand— one stab more or less is of little consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: When I had somewhat recovered from my first astonishment at your apprehension—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Where were you at that moment?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
Close by you; and when I saw you borne away, I was about to follow you down the street; but it soon occurred to me, that I might possibly render you more important service,
by seeking intelligence at the fountain-head. I was like one thunderstruck:—of the true motives for this proceeding, I could not entertain a doubt; but I had no conception of the pretext that would be urged to sanction it.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Well!—but my wife!—my wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I hastened back to the square, where I found the Prince's Valet-de-Chambre wrapped in a large cloak, and in waiting for his master's return—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh God!—Oh God!—the honour of my wife placed at the mercy of a Valet-de-Chambre!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: We had long known each other—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And he confided to you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The whole progress of the affair. Emilia with∣stood his solicitations for a long time—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (with an indignant sneer) Virtuous woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: She wept, knelt—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Extremely affecting!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But the Prince is young, handsome, engaging—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Perfectly natural▪

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And, perhaps, the idea of rank was too dazzling for the female imagination to resist; since the Prince promised à patent of nobility for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: He did me great honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And promotion at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Indeed!—that certainly was irresistable.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But by your own impetuosity, you have stumbled upon the very threshold.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, I am a headstrong fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You have done the Prince's work for him. It was impossible, that he could seriously intend to permit your re∣maining so near; he has long watched his opportunity, had his spies about in all parts—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And at last caught me trespassing upon his Prince∣ly territories!—damn him!—damn him!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Nor are his apprehensions yet removed; though a prisoner, he considers you as still a formidable obstacle to his views; and the Valet doubts whether you will be permitted to remain here. A removal to some more secure fortress, upon the frontiers, is talked of.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland! Morland! my heart bleeds for you!— Should his threat be executed, you were lost indeed!—Remote from every friend to console you, unknown, unpitied, branded by the mandate of the Prince himself, as a criminal—without even the possibility of communication by letter, with those who might pour a balm into your wounded mind—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: The same God is every where!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: No miracle will interpose to thwart the triumph of wickedness. Fly then, while it is yet in your power—my influ∣ence, my connections, may be of some service in screening you from pursuit—they can avail nothing, in case of your removal to a distant prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I will appeal to the laws!—a hearing cannot be refused me!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: To the laws!—Are you the first person who has been buried alive?—whose cries have in vain sought to force their way to the ear of justice?—And what purpose would be an∣swered, supposing you could obtain a hearing?—Is it not notori∣ous to all the world, that you are innocent, but who will venture to pronounce you so, when the Prince's honour is involved in the establishment of your guilt?—You are a foreigner; you have no relations, no connections, here, to concern themselves in your fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P:
Forsaken wretch that I am!—Oh, Emilia!—Emi∣lia!—Yes, Allbrand, I can readily conceive that the mind, even of a virtuous woman may be seduced by the allurements of am∣bition, by the blandishments of a voluptuary, till her honour be∣comes
their sacrifice—yet still, she has a heart!—Shame may, for a while, be silenced and put to flight; but, at length, it will return, strew the bed of roses with thorns, and change the smile of passion into convulsive distortions. Then will busy recollection reproach her, that for two years her love had been my all—that my heart, my life, had been devoted to the promotion of her happiness—that I had sacrificed every thing to my love—had known no joy without her—no sorrow when she was by my side! —Oh-h-h!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland, you rend my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And can this wife wish my destruction!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Whatever she may do now, terror must soon com∣pel her to wish it!—the dread lest all her misdeeds should become known, and your just vengeance overtake her.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, she was so affectionate!—could she see these cold drops that stand upon my forehead!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: She would hide the blush of shame in the bosom of her seducer.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Ha! For the love of heaven, Allbrand, shake me! rouse me!—that I may be awakened from this terrible dream!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Would to God, it were but a dream!—Did you see his Highness give her his hand at the house-door?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Was it indeed the Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Nay, you must yourself have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I saw the figure of a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Of the Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Damn him?—damn him!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And did you not hear?—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I heard nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Not the flatteries with which he received her—nor the burst of laughter behind the door, when you were arrested?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Laughter!—But it could be only the Prince who laughed!—I swear, by heaven, it could not be Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I might be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: No, Allbrand, a beloved wife may be so lost as to become a criminal; she may disgrace the name, and wring the heart of her injured husband: but could I suppose her capable of laughing, when she beheld innocence and virtue trampled under foot—when she saw that injured, deceived husband, thus made the victim.—O God!—O God!—See Allbrand! (he draws his hand out from his bosom, and shews it all bloody) fool!— fool!—I have torn my own flesh through indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Horrible, but just wrath!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Could she see these bloody fingers—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Rouse thyself, Morland!—Sue out a bill of divorce against the Syren!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: No, death alone shall separate us!—Yes, yes, she is dead!—See there she lies!—I wring my hands over her corpse! —Oh, God! assist me to believe in this illusion!—Emilia dead, I can love her again;—How that thought consoles me!—I can weep again!— (bursts into tears)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: One day will be sufficient to prepare all things for your escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Allbrand, bespeak me a suit of mourning.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Hasten to the arms of your aged father!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: A mourning suit, Allbrand!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Let your sister be the companion of your flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: A mourning suit for my deceased Emilia!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Morland, this is unmanly!—Will you waste your∣self to a shadow with fruitless sorrow, while the sorceress makes you her sport in the arms of her paramour?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Her sport!—No, Allbrand!—Emilia, though fallen, cannot make me her sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
Well, well, no matter!—In twenty-four hours, you will be upon the road to Basil—then, and not till then, when the traitress finds that she is not to enjoy her triumph in security,
will she be fully unmasked. Write her a letter, Morland—a letter full of coldness and contempt—a mandate of external se∣paration.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Do you suppose that the Prince's guards will con∣vey a letter from me to Emilia?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I will carry it to her—will give it to her in the presence of the Prince himself—strike her with a look—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Will you, indeed?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I give you my word of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Well, then!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (calls) Without there! (enter Kroll with Eve) Bring pen and ink.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: I did not know that it was permitted—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I will be responsible.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: The next room is prepared for the Syndicus; and here you will find all conveniences—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I will be with you again directly. (Kroll lights him to his room and returns)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (aside) I have managed it at last, but with infi∣nite trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Poor gentleman!—for certain, he must be innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: 'Tis possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: May one be allowed to ask what crime he has commit∣ted?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: That cannot be known for certain, it is a State secret; various reports are circulated.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Heaven will bring his innocence to light.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: That might be possible, if heaven and he were up∣on better terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: I don't understand what your honour means.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Strange things are reported of him—I cannot say positively, that they are true; but certain it is, that I never saw him at church.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: But still, I am sure he would not—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible to say!—bad company is contagi∣ous!—wicked books, and evil examples, have great influence.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Thus far I know from his own mouth, that he does not believe in a devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Not believe in a devil!—Eve, what d'ye think now?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And the Prince is extremely pious.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: To be sure he is. Well, well, his Highness has done quite right.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You see, my friends, that your compassion is mis∣placed.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Compassion, indeed!—I say compassion to a man who does not believe in a devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: 'Tis hard enough, that we are obliged to be under the same roof with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Should he attempt to converse with you, I would advise you to be short in your answers.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: You need not make yourself uneasy about that.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: No one, beside myself, must be allowed to speak with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Nobody but Satan. God forgive me the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Least of all, his wife. And, do you hear?—I again caution you against throwing yourselves too much in his way—a smooth tongue might conjole you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: He could not shake my faith. But the children, Ben∣jamin—he might do them a mischief.—We had best take care and keep the children out of his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: I will put a padlock upon his door.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: No, no, I cannot pity him any longer. I thought he might have committed some offence againt his Highness such as embezzling money entrusted to him, or some such matter; for such things will happen, even to the most pious. But not to believe in a devil!!!—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: —MORLAND returns with a letter in his hand, which he gives to ALLBRAND.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Take it!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (makes a sign to Kroll and Eve, who retire, when he unfolds the letter, and reads it to himself) 'Tis too wild!— too empassioned!—colder contempt had been better!—this anger will gratify her. However, (putting the letter in his pock∣et, and speaking aside) what the writer has omitted, the mes∣senger will supply.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (seizing his arm eagerly) Allbrand, should we at last be mistaken?—should she be innocent?—she might not survive the receipt of such a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I am a fool!—I am indeed a fool!— Did we not both see?—Ah, no!—I saw only her.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I saw, and heard, the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Are you very sure that you were not mistaken?— Our senses will sometimes deceive us—instances have occurred.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I was a cool spectator—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But in the darkness of night, you might be mis∣led—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The moon shone bright.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, too true!—too true!—and to attempt to ex∣plain away the whole affair by supposing it accident?—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Appears to me perfectly ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: So it is!—so it is!—Take the letter then!—yet hold!—No! no!—Allbrand, I think Emilia cannot possibly be innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Certainly not.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P:
Might not the Prince by chance?—No, that could scarcely be!—and what then could Emilia want?—to whom
could she go?—Oh, she is guilty!—she is guilty▪—every bond between us is broken—Take the letter, Allbrand; take it to her, paint to her my sufferings!—carry her my everlasting curse!— Yet! no! no! no!—for God's sake—she is pregnant!—All∣brand, she is pregnant!—give me back the letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You astonish me, Morland!—But since you are incapable of acting for yourself, I must think, and act for you— I must, and will save you. Recollect, that for four years past a dishonourable tie has chained Emilia to the Prince!—do you suppose that she would have forsaken the father of her child?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: You suggest horrors.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Will you submit to be reputed the father of a child not your own?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh God!—you drain the last drop of blood from my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Will you condescend to be made the laughing-ock of the whole country?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Ha!—revenge!—revenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Rather shew contempt. It is the part of injured orth to despise,—revenge must be left to conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Do you expect to find a conscience where virtue and ove have been so long dissembled?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: It cannot be enveloped in so thick a shell, but that worm of remorse will gnaw through to it at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P:
And when that moment shall arrive—when the of voluptuousness shall be exchanged for the bed of death, e criminal shall seek in vain for rest, upon the softest down—when the windows of her chamber must be at no ray of light may strike her languid eyes— e shall be insensible, even to the choicest wines 's cellar—whe o oling medicine shall have the fever burning in her vins—when hired ng by her bed-side, insensible to her faint
groans, to the scene of wretchedness before them!—then shall my form, just visible by the dusky glimmering of the midnight lamp, undraw her curtain—grin horribly at her with a ghastly smile, nod, menace, and vanish!—away!—away, with the letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Recover yourself, my friend; I go. The Prince shall hear harsh truths from me!—truth is the severest chastise∣ment that can be given to a Prince. (he is going, when Kroll enters, takes a light and accompanies him out▪)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV3.STAGE: —MORLAND alone. He pauses, looking after ALLBRAND.
DIV3.P: He is gone!—and what now am I?—Thus are all bonds that held me to the world, torn asunder, the bond of life alone ex∣cepted, and that can only be dissolved by a tedious series of ex∣cruciating torments!—yet, why await this lingering process?— down, down, with thee instantly to the grave, Morland, since thou hast no more to hope from man, save a handful of earth to cover thy bones!

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Will the gentleman be so good as to take himself to his chamber—this here is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: We have been kept up almost the whole night, entirely upon the gentleman's account.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Pardon me, good people!

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Nay, the Lord pardon thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: (with a pious sigh) And lead every one who is going astray, into the right road!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P:
(half aside) When only straying out of the right road, it is possible to be rescued; but whe fallen into the
abyss, nothing remains but to look down, and drop a tear upon the poor wretch who lies dashed to pieces below. But you don't understand me!—Good night! (Exit into his room)

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: (locking and barring the door of Morland's chamber) Yes, yes, we understand you very well!

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Did you hear how he talked about the Abyss?

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Of hell, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: Ah dear heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Kroll.
SP.P: Come wife, come to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Eve.
SP.P: He who does not believe in a devil, most likely does not believe in the good angels!—how can he ever sleep quietly in his bed! (Exeunt)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: —A room in MORLAND's house. THOMAS sitting asleep in a chair—a table standing by him, on which is a candle almost burnt out, and a watch. He starts from his sleep, rubs his eyes, and then rises.
DIV3.P: Three o'clock!—I don't know what to make of this!—he never used to be out so late!—I am afraid some misfortune has happened!—I would fain have gone with him, he looked so troub∣led in mind, but he ordered me to remain here. I am never quite easy at being alone; when two people are left together they can have a little chat, and that passes time away. Our good lady must not be told of this—for she'd fret herself to death; but I think I might wake Miss Jenny; and perhaps she knows more about the matter than I do.—I wonder, whether she would take it amiss?—I watched many a night upon her account, when she had the small-pox; and surely she can't think much of coming for once to comfort poor old Thomas?—Yes, I'll—I'll e'en venture it—and if she should be angry, I must tell her that "necessity has no law." (he taps at the door) Madam!—Miss Jenny!—She is young and sleeps sound!— (he taps again) Miss Jenny!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (within) Who knocks?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Only old Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: I want to know what is become of my master?— Pray, don't be angry Madam, it is now three o'clock, and I could not any longer restrain my uneasiness! (a violent knock∣ing is heard at the door) Zounds!—there he comes!—well, thank God!—thank God!—I might as well have let the young lady sleep on quietly. (Exit)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV3.STAGE: —JENNY enters from her room in a morning dress hastily slipped on.
DIV3.P: What can this mean?—why was I waked?—is there a fire in the neighbourhood?—The old man first frightened me from my sleep, and then ran away!—What a noise there is upon the stair∣case!—Who can be coming hither at this time of night?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (to Thomas) Away fool!—you will soon learn what we want! (seeing Jenny) Fair lady, reluctantly as I under∣took a commission which might disturb your rest, yet the sight of you banishes repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I do not understand you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: By command of his Highness, I come to seize your brother's papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: You cannot be serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (pointing to Pilz) The solemn severity of my companion's countenance, must preclude all idea of joking.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: My God! what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: A trifle!—only a little conspiracy!—a snug piece of treason against the State; no feminine concern, for there is not any love in the case. But I forget that my company was always disagreeable to you;—permit me therefore, to proceed with all expedition, in the fulfilment of his Highness's com∣mands.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Still, I do not understand you, Sir; and it were better that I awaken my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I should think he can hardly be asleep, since it is he who has awakened us; and a prison does not furnish very propitious quarters for the enjoyment of repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What do you mean?—my brother—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Has spent the last hour in the State prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (clasping his hands together) My God!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Heavens!—on what charge?
That he wanted to introduce into the State, what is only admissible in love,—liberty—and equality.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Infamous slander!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Then you have the less to apprehend from the examination of his papers. Come, Pilz, to your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Sir, I cannot suffer—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I am heartily sorry, Madam, that I must now for the first time in my life, disregard the interdict of a fair lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (half aside to Jenny, scarcely able to restrain his indignation) Madam, shall I call the coachman and groom?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Be quiet, Thomas. (to Scharfeneck) Sir, I require a written order.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You know, Madam, that I have the honour of being in the Prince's service; this officer of the police, and the guards below in the hall, must sufficiently prove that I obey the highest commands. How much rather had I come hither with∣out this formidable train, only upon an adventure of gallantry?— But your severity—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Matchless impudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (muttering to himself) Impudence indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (to Jenny) You were speaking of your servant, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: He never was impudent.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Fellow!—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Sir, I would have you to know that I am a Swiss, a free man.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—And so you also are playing that part.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny
SP.P: Be silent, Thomas;—Go and call my sister-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (going reluctantly, and muttering to himself) When people break into the house at dead of night, I know in my country— (Exit)

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I have waited too long.—As far as I remember, this is Mr. Morland's study—Pilz, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: For your own justification, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: May I request the key of your brother's desk?

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: He always carrys that about with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Then we must manage without a key.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Sir, I warn you that the Prince, shall know by day-break—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Unfortunate that I am, to be compelled to give the warnings of a fair lady to the wind. (he goes into Morland's study, followed by Pilz, carrying a lanrn)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I tremble!—I know not what to do!—How will my poor sister-in-law be shocked and terrified!—What fatal conse∣quences may not be apprehended!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (entering in haste and terror) New troubles!—new sorrows!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Good Heavens!—what?—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Our good lady is gone too!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Has never been in bed. Mary stole into her room, just opened her curtains, and called softly, "Madam,"—No answer!—She tapped with her hand upon the bed—all cold!— At last, she fetched the lamp and looked—nothing to be seen!— nothing to be heard!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Oh, God! what can be the meaning of this!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: She is most likely with my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: How can she have learned—

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Who knows?—She had perhaps a kind of a mis∣giving.—Such things often happen among people that love each other so very dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Then I am left quite alone!

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Don't be frightened, Madam,—old Thomas is here, and the good God is here; and if you would but let me call the Coachman and the Groom, we'd soon clear the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Go, Thomas, and call Mr. Smith.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Zounds! if I had not forgotten Mr. Smith!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Proper, or improper, I must send for him;—in times of distress, we concern ourselves little about propriety.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV3.STAGE: —Enter SCHARFENECK and PILZ with the papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: My errand is accomplished:—once more I en∣treat your pardon, Madam, and heartily wish you pleasant morning slumbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Yet another moment, Sir!—My brother's clerk will be here instantly, and I must request of you to tell him what papers—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: All, Madam!—every scrap!—I am not fond of selections.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: He is a man of business, and will know what should be granted, what refused.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: As to what concerns the papers, Madam, there is nothing either to grant, or to refuse; I must take them all. What else the clerk may grant or refuse here, I am too modest to enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: At least, I think you might respect misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I respect the rights of beauty, and should be perfectly inconsolable were a longer interruption of your rest to endanger the making of those lovely cheeks pale.—Come, Pilz, I fear we are intruders here. (Exit with a low sarcastic bow, followed by Pilz)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (bursting into tears) Why do I weep?—Why at such a moment, bestow one thought upon an insult that concerns my∣self alone?—This is not a time to waste in fruitless lamentations! —My poor brother!—my poor Emilia!—Oh that I were not a woman!—but my sex shall not withhold me!—I will go di∣rectly to the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Thomas tells me strange things.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Give me your advice, your assistance, dear Smith.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Mr. Morland, a prisoner—his papers seized—your sister-in-law not to be found!

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: 'Tis all but too true.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This is a cursed country.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: What shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Go to England, and live in freedom.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: But, at present—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: We must patiently wait the approach of day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And then?—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I do not doubt of being able to procure your bro∣ther's release.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: But how?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (After considering for a few minutes) Yes, I must speak. —My dearest Madam, many a book may be found in the world▪ which, though shabby to the eye from being uncut and unbound, will by its innate worth attract attention from the man of under∣standing, though it may be scorned by the coxcomb on account of its homely garb. Such a book is Honesty in the heart of a citizen, and Innocence in a plain coat; both are the est of the valets in the anti-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Is that, any source of consolation to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: By no means—I rather made the observation, to prove that your brother is lost, because, though his virtue is of sterling worth, the buckles in his shoes are not of equal value.—With Courtiers, the case is the very reverse.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Heavens!—Is this a moment for such remarks?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: The precise moment for them. You think me, per∣haps, cold, unfeeling to your distress—but you mistake—I am only composed through habit—because I have witnessed the like an hundred times. Man possesses the noble faculty of being able to habituate himself to any thing, save excess of happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And whither do these observations tend?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: To confessing that I feel myself reduced to the un∣pleasant necessity of using baser coin, where nobility of soul will not pass as currency. I will go to the Minister, announce my∣self as Lord Sidney—

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Smith, are you awake?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I will present him with a letter of recommendation from our Minister; nor do I doubt that the Lord will obtain a hearing, when the humble clerk would be spurned.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Smith, do you speak seriously?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Most seriously, dearest Madam. Influenc by love, the eccentric being you behold, laid aside his rank, till he could fully assure himself, whether a Lord was of more account in your estimation, than an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I am astonished!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Why astonished?—Love and caprice have frequently wrought changes even more extraordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: My Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Oh, no!—My Lord will go to rescue your brother: but Edward Smith will return hither to solicit your hand. I have a fine estate in Warwickshire, a true Swiss country, which wants nothing to render it a complete Paradise, but those delight∣ful inhabitants Love and Liberty. What think you, Madam? —I now rejoice, that I am rich; since I have enough for us all—enough to support us all happily together.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I am incapable at present of making any reply to offers so generous.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You will never meet with one whose intentions are more honorable.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Shall necessity grant what love asks?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Nobly urged!—I will therefore be silent, nor solicit you farther. Repentance is every where an evil guest; and if it enter the abode of Love, is too apt to destroy the host.—But the day begins to dawn—I will hasten to the Minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: And I, to my poor brother's prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Allow me to take your hand, Madam! (He presses her hand most tenderly to his lips) —I am not accustomed to use many words; but God, who knows my heart, knows that I love you! (Exit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: I am quite overpowered!—I could weep like a child! Fye! fye! Jenny,—lay aside the woman, and think only of thy brother!—Gold will procure thee access to him, sooner than tears. (Exit.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XVII.
DIV3.STAGE: —Captain ELLFIELD's Lodging. The Cap∣tain, Mrs. ELLFIELD. and EMILIA discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I rejoice indeed, Madam, to find you thus. Appetite and sleep, are the most infallible symptoms of returning health; and, thanks be to God, for some days past, you seem to have amended very rapidly;—but you must still be careful.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I urge the same to her every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: The weather was so fine—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: But the air was cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Indeed, the walk has been of great service to me. The fresh air, the benign rays of the sun, gave me new life.—I seemed to inhale strength with every breeze.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: But you should have gone early to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: I would fain have persuaded her to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I slept, for some hours, upon the Sopha; and I could not refuse myself the pleasure of receiving my bene∣factress.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: If I have deserved this name, I am richly repaid. I leave you for the first time, with satisfaction;—it grows late. (she puts on her cloak) I cannot now determine, when we shall meet again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Will you not allow two grateful hearts to pay their respects to you in your own house?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Then, I must tell you who I am, and where I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Is it not cruel, to conceal it from us any longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Dear Captain, allow me to follow my own humour. In a week, I will receive you, when I shall introduce another person to your acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: But how, if the veil of this amiable modesty have no proved sufficiently thick, to conceal you from the penetrating eyes of gratitude?—How, if your name be already known to us?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Our faith has been inviolably observed.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: You surely cannot have watched me home?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: No, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Then you cannot know my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: The name of Morland can never be erased from our hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (with astonishment) Ha!—indeed you do know me! —Oh, say how has this happened?—by what means have you guessed my secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: If you will trust to my word of honour, that the information was unsought by us; I would rather bury in obli∣vion a hateful circumstance—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: You but increase my curiosity; I am certain that my secret is not known to any one in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Are you equally certain that you have never been watched?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: How!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Ha!—you here again!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
