SP.P: Secretary Allbrand!—I am astonished!—What can bring you hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Yes, Sir!—I desire to know your errand?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I can scarcely recover breath. Pardon this unsea∣sonable visit!— (to Emilia) I must entreat, Madam, for a few minutes, private conversation with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: With me?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (to Ellfield) Sir, I conjure you, if you possess the feelings of humanity, to allow me a few minutes alone with this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Not, unless it be her desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: What can you have to say in private with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Oh, for heaven's sake, do not delay a moment!— time is precious.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: If I alone am concerned, I have no secrets from these good people.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: My business concerns your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (with a look of suspicion) Indeed!—Well a lie can avail you little—a few moments, my friends—but do not go far.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: We shall remain in the next room. (Exit with Mrs. Ellfield)

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Now, what is your business?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Alas! that I must be the messenger of ill news!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Ill news!—but go on!—we know each other already! —What is your news?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: My friend, your husband—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Do you seek to lead my senses astray through terror?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: What mortifying distrust!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Speak out at once!—What has happened to your friend, as you are pleased to call him?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You seem extremely composed, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: My nerves are not weak▪ Mr. Secretary;—I do not faint away, at a spider's crawling about my neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Do I deserve to be treated with such scorn?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Ask that question of yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I only entreat you to forget at this moment, the errors of love, and to listen solely to the voice of friendship!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I am all attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Your husband is at this moment in close confinement in the State Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (disdainfully) Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He is accused of exciting sedition.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Really!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: His papers are seized.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: And of what use do you suppose this story can be to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: You do not then believe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: I certainly do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Would to God that this were the worst part of my information.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: The worst part!—What more have you to relate? Let me hear all.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Whether Morland be guiltless or not of the State crimes imputed to him, I shall not now enquire—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: No enquiry is necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: But that he is criminal towards his wife will not admit of a doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Towards me!—well, to what extent?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Must he believe you accessary to his arrest, only because you prudently concealed from him some former trans∣actions—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (Starting) Former transactions!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Could not he who knows you so well, give you cre∣dit for the purity of your motives?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Morland knows then—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: That you once received certain offers from the Prince—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And he asserts, that he has positive evidence of this connection.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (With dignity) Sir, there never was any connection between me and the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Who is more convinced of that than myself?— But Morland—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Has some evil daemon possessed him?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Unworthy of your tender and faithful affection, he even threatens a separation.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: A separation!—from me!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He forgets, that the indignation of a virtuous woman, who feels herself injured, burns most fiercely amid the ashes of extinguished love.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Secretary Allbrand, I desire you to forbear breathing forth your poisonous exhalations, and to speak more plainly—for by Heaven, I do not understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He has discovered your nightly visits to this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Emila.
SP.P: Dishonour light upon the head of him who betrayed them.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: And he believes his honour injured—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: He knows me!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: He ought to know you!—his suspicions therefore, are the more unpardonable: his determination never to see you again the more horrible.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Hence from my sight, liar!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Would to heaven I were a liar!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Allbrand, if there be any thing in the world that you esteem sacred, swear by it!—

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I swear by your virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P:
Villain! dare not thus to profane my virtue!—Fool that I am!—Why do I stand here patiently listening to that
baleful tongue, when in a few moments I might be in Morland's arms, and then would this whole scene of villainy be exposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Whither would you go, unhappy woman? Mor∣land languishes in prison—he cannot see you—and if he could he will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Allbrand, what can be your aim in all this?—Do you seek to lead my senses astray by these horrible falsehoods?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: What end could I propose in uttering falsehoods which must be detected the moment you entered your own house?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Must I then indeed believe Morland to be a prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Yet be composed, and do not therefore consider yourself as deserted—A friend still remains to you, one who can forget unmerited humiliations—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: And must I also believe that Morland intends to sepa∣rate himself from me? Oh God! Oh God!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Insulted Virtue, summon thy elder brother, Pride, to thy supporr!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Man, what hast thou done!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: What have I done?

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Thou alone wert capable of spinning such an infernal web!—Daemon, what hast thou done?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: These injurious suspicions, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: But do not exult too soon! The Prince shall give back a citizen to the state—love shall restore a husband to my arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: What dependence is to be placed on that love, this letter will inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: God of heaven!—my husband's hand! (s atches open the letter—reads it—drops it from her hand— ggers— sinks on her knees—utters a loud shriek, and faints.)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Have I subdued thy spirit at last!—Oh, sweet, sweet revenge— (exit hastily, casting a malignant look upon Emi∣lia as he goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: What is the matter!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Merciful heaven! what do I see?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Our benefactress! (they raise Emila up and place her in a chair) what can have become of the villain? (he sup∣ports Emilia)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: (seeing the letter upon the ground, takes it up and reads it) May I believe my eyes? Can this be possible?— read!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (after reading the letter) Is this the result of her be∣nevolent visits to us?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Ellfield.
SP.P: That she should incur such a horrible suspi∣cion!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: That she should be supposed here—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield,
SP.P: In a house of such a description—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Oh God! my honour!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Think, dear Charles, on all her kindness; to her alone are we indebted that you have still a wife—hasten, hasten then, to Morland's prison—a single word may develope this scandalous imposition!—No, I will go myself—where is my cloak—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Dearest Caroline, you would not—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Shall we repay her angelic benevolence by re∣maining cold spectators of misery endured for our sakes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: But should admittance be refused?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P:
I will hasten to the minister—his palace shall resound with my cries and lamentations, till they reach his ears; My countenance of anguish will awaken the compassion even of
courtiers, my convulsive agonies irresistibly seize their atten∣tion. I am certain I shall gain admittance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: But you are ill and weak.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Oh no—never did I feel myself stronger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Let me go, I entreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: No, remain here to console her—of that I am incapable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: Dear Caroline, you will be too much agitated—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: To see her agonies, when she first recovers, would agitate me still more;—and to bring back a misguided husband into the arms of a faithful wife, would be the most powerful cordial I could experience. (she puts on her cloak)— console our unfortunate friend, my Charles, I shall soon return. Heaven prosper my efforts! (Exit hastily)

SP.SPEAKER: Ellfield.
SP.P: (still supporting Emilia) Where will this end!—Oh fate! fate!—in what various ways hast thou strewed my path of life with thorns! (Emilia sighs deeply and opens her eyes) Her senses seem returning—Madam!— (Emilia fixes her eyes upon him, then thrusts him gently from her, and looks round the room with a vacant stare. By degrees her recollection seems to return, when she strkes both hands upon her frehead, and bursts into tears. Ellfield again addresses her) Recover yourself, Ma∣dam,—all will soon be well!— (Emilia maes signs to him to be silent, she clasps her hands together, sinks p her knees, and raises her eyes towards Heaven in silent prayer—Ellfiel kneels by her) Oh, God, to thee I address my supplications—save.— in mercy save,—our benefactress!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: —The room in which the Minister receives company. Several Card-Tables set out, with Cards strewn upon them, and Candles standing nearly burnt out. The Time is early in the Morning. PRUNE is busied in collecting the Cards and Card-My.

SP.SPEAKER: PRUNK.
SP.P: TO the honour of the Spaniards, two inventions are to be asbed to them, the Inquisition and the Cards;—both power∣ful bulwarks, against heresy and languor, and in many respects bearing a strong resemblance to each other. The Inquisition prevents philosophical investigation,—so do Cards.—Cards occa∣sion ple cheeks and hollow eyes,—so does the Inquisition.— The Inquisition stifles all the natural affections,—so do Cards.— The for Cards brings many a sacrifice to the gallows,—the Inquisition carries an equal number to the blazing pile. But the nce of Cards is still more extensive than that of the Inquisition—for the latter, only seizes upon Jews and Hereticks, Cards do not spare any sect or age, not even the most female devotees.—Peace to the ashes of him who invented !—may his bones be cut into dice, and his portrait every king of diamonds!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Your honour's most obedient.—Why so late?—o whither so early?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Is my uncle risen?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He is ill with a head-ach.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Has he any company?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Yes, the Mastiff.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I must speak with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: I do not know whether—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Pilz, leave the papers here.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: Mr. Secretary Allbrand ordered me—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Allbrand ordered you!—What?—

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: To carry them to his room.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: There's no occasion for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: He charged, me upon my conscience—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Your conscience!—a pretty kind of charge, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: But, it seemed to be of great importance to the Secre∣tary.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Enough Pilz,—I have my reasons;—and that's more than I can always say.

SP.SPEAKER: Pilz.
SP.P: If you will take upon yourself, to be answerable—

DIV3.STAGE: (he lays the papers upon the table, bows, and withdraws)

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Prunk, I have struck a grand stroke.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Met with girl?—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: No, no,—rendered a service to the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: To the State?—that means, in this country, to the Prince;—therefore I repeat my question?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Thou art a wise one. No, Prunk, the service is not quite so important; I have only caught a Jacobin.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: By name?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Syndicus Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Morland a Jacobin?—No, no, that won't do!—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Why do you doubt it?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: He looks every body in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: What can be more suspicious? He shows a want of diffidence, very unbecoming in a subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: And he always says what he thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: A sign that he thinks too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: A new species of crime.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Far from it!—It has always been thought pru∣dent to keep fools, and wise-men, coiners, and thinkers, in con∣finement.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: But, if you have no other proofs—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: These papers contain the proofs. Now, my uncle will no longer have reason to complain, that I do not ap∣ply to any thing. I have forsaken both a Card-Table and a rendezvous—sacrificed a whole night—

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: To plunge a worthy man into distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: An impertinent remark, Prunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Truth always sounds to Courtiers, like an ill-tuned violin.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I have followed you closely, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (to Prunk) Is the Porter ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, he snarled very properly at me,—but I know these people very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Probably, you had a great deal of conversation with each other?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I understand you.—His rank would have been no objection to me,—but his profession—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Indeed!—had he then fortunately been a shoe∣maker?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You are right—for then he had probably been an in∣dustrious and useful man. But a Porter, and a Gentleman of the Privy-Chamber, are commonly good for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Fellow, are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I have rather proved the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Prunk, lend me your brawny hands to chastise his impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Do not give yourselves that trouble—I shall not stir from this place, till I have spoken with the minister;—then— you will find me any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (somewhat embarrassed) Prunk!—

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: No noise must be made here.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (to Smith) This to me in my uncle's house!—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Young man, I pity you from my soul!—It is a great misfortune to you, that your uncle is minister.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Your language—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Was once not unfamiliar to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Indeed—it appears to me—as if—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Can we have a little private conversation?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Prunk. (he gives Prunk a nod, who retires)

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Now eccentric Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
To justify that appellation, I will begin with relating a story. In the course of my rambles, I once came to a small town, the romantic situation of which charmed me, and I re∣mained
for several weeks fixed to the spot. It was surrounded by a chain of hills, at whose foot meandered a beautiful stream; and these were my daily haunt. One evening I had stayed out very late, and was wandering solitarily homewards, by twilight, along the water-side, when suddenly I saw and heard, among the trees, a female form, wringing her hands violently, and uttering deep sighs and groans, as she staggered backwards and forwards, to the brink of the river. Curiosity induced me to conceal myself that I might observe her farther; and, in a few moments, I saw her plunge into the stream. I am a good swimmer; I sprung in after her, and was fortunate enough so save her life: yet she did not thank me for—What think you, young gentleman, of the privy chamber?—what reason do you suppose she gave for this attempt at self-destruction?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (extremely confused) How can I guess?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Well, well, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: "I am, said she, the daughter of an humble citizen, and possessed no other wealth, but my honour and innocence. Of these, a young man, a student here, sought to beguile me: but failing in his attempt, he had recourse to a most cruel revenge. He traduced my character in all companies; till at length, wherever I went, the neighbors pointed at me with their fingers; my former friends looked askance at me; and worse than all, my lover, an honest mechanic—oh, terrible to think on! desert∣ed me. I could not support myself against such undeserved ig∣nominy, I was driven to despair, and I resolved to put an end to my life." You do not seem well, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (with downcast eyes, and twirling his fingers) Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
At first I supposed the slandere to be wholly worth∣less; but I was mistaken; he was only thoughtless. I went to him with the frmness of an honest man, painted to him in forci∣ble
colours, the poor girl's misery, and the disastrous consequen∣ces of his chattering vanity: he was shocked at the story; I saw tears of remorse rush into his eyes; the blush of shame suffuse his cheeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (stretching out his arms) Edward Smith!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: He had sufficient magnanimity instantly to recant his former errors, and to proclaim aloud the maiden's innocence, and his own criminality. Repentance, and assiduous kindness, washed out the stains that calumny had made, and on my bosom he thanked heaven, that I had saved him, before it was too lat to repair his fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (throwing himself upon his neck) Edward Smith!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You now recollect my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: With shame, that I could forget your person. Edward, we then exchanged promises of perpetual friend∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith,
SP.P: Which you are not ashamed to own?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Do not suppose me sunk quite so low!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I am only Morland's clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I am only a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
(shaking his hand warmly) Right! and like that unfortunate girl you have plunged into a rushing stream, whence I may perhaps equally succeed in rescuing you. Young man, that dreadful example ought to have served you as a warning; under its influence you made me a solemn promise to subdue your fatal propensity to calumny: but ask your heart how faith∣fully that promise has been kept. Though all who have become sacrifices to your tongue, may not have made like attempts up∣on their lives, yet who can tell how many a bitter tear has been shed in secret, of which you only were the cause: how much domestic happiness may have been destroyed by one word alone, perhaps carelessly uttered by you. The ears of mankind are
always open for the reception of slander, but are often inflexibly closed against all attempts at its refutation: a hint is easily given, but its effects cannot easily be calculated: a thought∣less word trips lightly over the tongue; but it cannot be recal∣led by the Almighty himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: You have a right to reproach me thus: yet at present I do not deserve—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: What had Morland done to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He was considered as dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Calumny!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He espoused the citizens' cause with great warmth.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: It was his duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: He is a thorn in the eyes of some persons.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: There is the thing, Allbrand—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Even so!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And can you suffer yourself to be made the tool of such a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I consider myself as performing my duty to my uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Young man, your head and heart received from na∣ture a proper bias. Rose yourself then from this unworthy in∣toxication: Let an Allbrand cringe as he pleases: but do not suffer yourself to be infected with the poison. You might be splendid by virtue: and you only glitter by rank: You might enlighten from merit, and you only dazzle with wit. Your heart would gain you friends, but they are repulsed by your head: you might attract love, and you only coquet with fear. To slander a worthy man, who is peaceably following his own pursuits, is no less base, than to murder one who sleeps: and to re-establish the character of the undeserved victim of calumny, is a task scarcely less difficult, than to smooth over scars of the small-pox.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Here is my hand: never will I give you cause of complaint in future.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: As an earnest of your sincerity, save Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I give you my honour, that whatever is in my power shall be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Where are his papers?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Upon this table.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Will you deliver them into your uncle's hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: What will you say to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: That they are lost—burnt—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (calls) Prunk!

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (entering from the anti-chamber) Your Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (aside to Scharfeneck) Now is your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What a noise has there been here this morning: 'tis a shameful breach of decorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: This stranger—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What does he want?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I beg your Excellency's pardon for coming so late.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (looking at his watch and smiling) So late?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Too late for one in whose house justice never slum∣bers: too late when the question is to vindicate an innocent man whom calumny has unjustly thrown into prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: One who will esteem himself most happy, most worthy of envy, should he succeed in rescuing innocence from undeser∣ved odium—and in saving your Excellency's fame from incurring the stain of injustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (contemptuously) You!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: So looked the snared lion upon the mouse, till she had gnawed the net in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: In whose behalf do you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: In behalf of the worthiest man in the town—Syndi∣cus Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Ha! where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: In a place of all others the least proper for him—in prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And where was the bird caught?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: (confused) Secretary Allbrand will inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Relate all that you know, but let truth alone guide the narrative: before her, my friend will never blush nor I grow mute.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The truth, young sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Mr. Morland stole at midnight—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: 'Tis false, he never stole.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: No interruption, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: The Syndicus was going at midnight, to visit the Captain Ellfield, who lives in the Castle Square—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Impossible, he does not know any body of that name.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Yes, the Captain is well known both to the Syndi∣cus and ourselves. But, proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: When, just as he entered the house he was ar∣rested.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: At whose comand?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: At mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: Secretary Allbrand immediately dispatched me to seize his papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: And where are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: By an unlucky accident— (he stops extreme∣ly embarrassed)

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Here they lie!—the property of a citizen, under the protection of the first officer of the State.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: They must be examined.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: By what authority?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (starting indignantly) Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Justice would not shrink from the question, and e who stands in the Prince's place, ought not to be offended at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Once more, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: An Englishman, and at present clerk to Mr. Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Esteem for your nation, could alone induce me to pardon such boldness.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Speak pardon to the criminal!—undisguised truth may not suit t mass of mankind; but from the nobl ded Minister of Justice, it will be received with transport.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: The man in whose behalf you speak with such true English licence, lies under strong suspicion of holding dangerous principles.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: By whom is he accused?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: 'Tis well that you are come—your prudence keeps you watchful—now complete your work, unmask a suspicious character, and justify measures which appear despotic in the eyes of this Englishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
This man, his accuser!—My Lord Count, before one word shall pass those impure lips, I entreat you to hear me!— Secretary Allbrand was a daily guest at Morland's, and was con∣sidered as his bosom friend. He has shared those moments when wine encreases the circulation of the blood, and when an ardent feeling will often burst out in unguarded wods. He was always courteous, always pliant, had always a complaent nod of the head ready for every opinion which was thrown out, —a smile at command for every sally of wit. Possessing in an eminent degree the faculty of drawing forth whatever he wish∣ed
to know, he has availed himself of the unreserved moments of social mirth, to ruin the man he pretended to love,—he has watched every turn of conversation at table, and dipping his pen in gall, noted down any innocent piece of humour uttered by his honest host, to make use of it as opportunity should offer for trampling him under foot, and ingratiating himself with the court. Count Scharfeneck surely will not listen to such an accuser.—When a man of honor is called to account, a man of honor alone should be heard against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (To Allbrand) You stir not hence, till you hav pro all your accusations.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Am I to guess at the question before you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Oh, the innocent hesitation!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Morland is arrested.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Of that I can inform your Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Declare before this gentleman, why he is arrested.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: For arrogant assumptions, indiscreet conversation, and suspicious intercourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: And where are your proofs?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: With respect to his arrogance, I need only remind your Excellency of the manner in which he has defended the rights of the citizens, as he is pleased to term them.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A man who would perform his duty, must speak with firmness.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Of his indiscreet conversation, your Excellency's nephew, the Gentleman of the Privy Chamber, has often been witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (Scharfeneck.) Is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck..
SP.P: (With firmness) No.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: How, nephew,—have you not yourself—

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P:
Yes uncle, I confess it with shame;—but God be my witness, I was then a slanderer; nor reflected upon the consequences!—Thoughtlessness and bad example misled me; but the happiness of a worthy man is concerned, and I am re∣called
to myself. Morland's house is a school of morals, his table the rendezvous of innocent cheerfulness—his jokes never wound—his serious conversation is full of instruction, and no captious expression ever escapes his lips. Love for the town he inhabits, affection for the Prince, and respect for my uncle, reign in his bosom. As such I know him: and whoever represents him otherwise, were it my uncle himself, I would say that be misrepresents him and deserves correction.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Worthily spoken, young man! Can any thing more be wanting to establish Mr. Morland's innocence, than this un∣suspicious testimony?—Oh, Count! let your ears be closed against the voice of calumn▪ The slanderer is the most nge∣rous of all the traitors to the state, for he unites all crimes in one. He is a thief who steals into men's houses, and robs them of more precious treasures than gold and silver—he is a murder∣er who attacks the inoffensive and unarmed, and deprives them of even more than life. Restore to the State a citizen, to whom his duty was ever sacred, and who has too dearly atoned for his only weakness—placing confidence in this man.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: The true declamation of an associate in his crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Base soul!—is that thy last resource?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Justice remains cool!—it is fortunate for me, that my patriotic zeal is fully known to his Excellency.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Why this altercation?—Morland's papers will elucidate the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: They are in my apartment, and shall be laid before your Excellency this very day.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: They are here; they may be examined instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (starting, and appearing to be extremely confound∣ed) How!—What!—I ordered—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
Once more, my Lord Count, let me entreat your forbearance towards these papers!—I am unacquainted with their contents: I never was in Morland's confidence: yet I
would venture to pledge my life that they contain nothing im∣proper. But Mr. Morland is a philosopher and a poet: and in the course of philosophical investigation, or in the composition of poetry, things are often hastily written, which were never inten∣ded for any other eye than the writer's. A random line may condemn a man, only for want of being considered in connexion with the context—the writing-desk is a friend to whom we con∣fide every effusion of the heart, or imagination—has any one a right to put this friend to the rack? or if he possessed it, would he avail himself of the right?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: These observations may be just: but they only increase my curiosity.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Curiosity is a feeling that a Judge must suppress.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: There is such a variety of other business awaiting your Excellency this morning, that I had better previously ex∣amine the papers in my own apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: They shall remain here.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Indeed, that gentleman is perfectly in the right— Many things may have escaped the pen of a philosopher and poet, never intended to see day-light. I would select only such papers as can in any way interest the state: and thus save your Ex∣cellency much trouble, and many precious moments.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: This, when you believe—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I beg your Excellency's pardon, but I must now recal my former request, and entreat no less earnestly, that the papers may be opened. The Secretary is embarrassed—he seeks to prevent it—this cannot be without good reasons—Good reasons, my Lord Count—good you know is a relative term.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Sir, you are abusive—I know you not—I have ne∣ver offended you: but I will not forget who I am. I refer my∣self to his Excellency for satisfaction—for my own part, I find that I had better retire: since not even the presence of the first minister can secure me against affronts. (he snatches up the pa∣pers hastily and is going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (stepping before the door) Hold!—You stir not hence!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Mr. Clerk, your impertinence exceeds even my patience—Prunk call the guards. (exit Prunk.)

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (taking out his pocket-book) My Lord Count, it is with reluctance, that I am obliged to avail myself of a letter of recommendation, which I have reserved only for a case of ex∣treme exigence. (he gives the Minister a letter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (contemptuously) You a letter of recommendation to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I beg you to break it open.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (opens the letter, looks at the signature, starts and exclaims) WILLIAM PITT! (He reads the letter to himself, astonishment and confusion appear alternately in his countenance when he has finished, he turns with great courtesy to Smith)— I—if I do not immediately—if I do not understand— Prunk, a chair!—My Lord, so earnest a recommendation was wholly superfluous for a man who has distinguished himself so nobly—Prunk, why don't you bring a chair!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Your Excellency will excuse me, if I defer to a fu∣ture opportunity, of acquainting you with the motives which oc∣casioned my appearing thus incognito.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: No one has any right to question your Lordship upon that subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: National humour may perhaps be offered as the principal cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (presenting his Nephew with great solemnity)—My Lord, the Gentleman of the Privy-Chamber, Von Scharfeneck— Nephew, my Lord Sidney.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (giving his hand to Scharfeneck with a smile) We are already known to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (entering) Please your Excellency, the guards are ready in the anti-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Silence!—My Lord, I hope you will give his Highness the pleasure—

DIV3.STAGE: (Allbrand, during this scene, has been watching an opportuni∣ty to escape: but Smith, who has still kept his eye fixed upon him, seeing him attempt to slide to the door, seizes him somewhat roughly by the arm)

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This gentleman appears so extremely anxious to escape with these papers, that I must once more request they may be opened in my presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: They shall be examined instantly. Yet let me assure your Lordship, that you have mistaken my secretary, of whose fidelity and activity I have the most convincing proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Then I pity the honourable man, that nature has be∣stowed on him a countenance which seems destined to the gal∣lows.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Come Allbrand, unseal the papers! Why this hesitation?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I obey. His Lordship must himself acknowledge the truth of what is alledged: provided nothing be suppressed which may tend to inculpate the accused.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: His Excellency has forbidden any preface.

STAGE.HI: The Minister, Smith, and Allbrand, range themselves rund the table, the papers are unsealed, and the Minister examines them.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Accounts settled—Acquittances—Letters— (he opens the letters) From his father in Switzerland—Phylosophi∣cal reflections upon the immortality of the soul—Letters and verses to my wife—Secret benefactions—"In case of my death, my wife is requested to continue this list exactly as they are here noted down.—Ode to spring.—Sketch of a poem for the children of Count von Scharfeneck, for their father's birth-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: Their young excellency's lately begged that of him very earnestly. Your Excellency's birth-day happens in the course of next week.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Indeed!—Ah, I have made an ill return for this! (he proceeds in his examination) Drawings.—A Song, with mu∣sic—Actions which appear to be well-grounded—Deduc∣tions—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (hasttly to Allbrand) What are you hiding there?

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: (looking extremely confused) Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Produce it.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Instantly! (Allbrand lays the paper on the ta∣ble with a trembling hand, the Minister takes it up and reads) "PATRIOTIC REFLECTIONS thrown together, at the REQUEST of my friend ALLBRAND."—How!—I hope this is not!— (he runs over the paper hastily) It is so indeed—the very work— verbatim et literatim—Mr. Secretary, this is the treatise which first recommended you to my favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I beg your Excellency's pardon—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Oh, shame! shame!—You have pressed all the juice of the ripened fruit, and now would trample the rind into the dust—Misguided wretch that I have been!—But Mor∣land's innocence is sufficiently established; hasten, Nephew, to release him from his shameful bondage. Order that my car∣riage be made ready; it shall follow you and bring you the Syndicus hither from the prison. I owe a public atonement to the worthy man; and it shall be made in the presence of you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Scharfeneck.
SP.P: I hasten to execute the most glorious commis∣sion with which I was ever entrusted. (exit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
I see the whole extent of my misfortune—Mor∣land's enlargement includes with it my condemnation. Heaven grant that your Excellency may not have proceeded rashly!—I acknowledge that I was indebted to the Syndicus for this trea∣tise: but with my principles I could not suffer a private obliga∣tion to interfere with my prior duty to my country. I rejoice that nothing suspicious has bpen found in those papers; yet the falsehood of the charges brought against the accused, is by
no means proved. Your Excellency will recollect, that a very important circumstance yet remains uninvestigated—the secret intercourse that has long subsisted between Mr. Morland and Captain Ellfield—his stolen visits at midnight—

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Is not the serpent's venom yet exhausted? A female voice without, in a tone of great anxiety. I must speak with him!

SP.SPEAKER: A servant without.
SP.P: His Excellency cannot spare time.

SP.SPEAKER: The female voice approaching the door.
SP.P: I will go in.

SP.SPEAKER: The servant.
SP.P: Go back!—Go back!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: (to Prunk) See what is the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (opening the door) Some strange lady—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: —MRS. ELLFIELD rushes in wildly. Her countenance is pale and ghastly—she staggers and looks eagerly round on all present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Which is the Minister?

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I am he, Madam—Whom do I behold?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: The wife of Captain Ellfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Come hither, I imagine, to support your husband's petition for a pension.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: No, my Lord, want would never have indu∣ced me to enter the Chamber of a Prime Minister: I was born in the great world, and well know what kind of reception a beg∣gar meets with about a Court. (she supports herself against the back of a chair.)

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: (reaching her a seat) You seem ill, madam—sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I thank you, sir. Yet you remind me of my illness at an unseasonable moment. (she sees Allbrand) Ha! Villain! You here!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: What a you by that, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Oh, welcome, auxiliary!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I have not the honour of knowing the lady, who accosts me so familiarly.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Explain yourself, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I will, my Lord: yet not to waste the little strength possessed by one scarcely restored to life, upon a vil∣lain, but to save the guiltless, to vindicate the aspersed character of an angel.—How my husband fought for his native country: how he was crippled in her service: and what recompense his valour has received, you already know—The long and painful confinement he underwent, in recovering from his wounds, ex∣hausted at once our slender means, and my health: and scarcely was he able to rise from the bed of sickness, when I was seized with a dreadful fever. The delirium attendant upon my disor∣der, deprived me for two months of all sense of our sorrows: and I had sunk unknown, unnoticed, into the grave, had not an accident conducted a lady, a total stranger to us, into our garret. To her benevolence alone, am I indebted for my recovery: she attended me with the affection of a sister: her purse, her heart, were ours: yet she kept her name in concealment: nor knew we till yesterday, when a villainous accident revealed it to us.— (casting a pointed look at Allbrand) that Mrs. Morland was our benefactress.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Excellent woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: She came to us only by night: and at the ap∣proach of morning, returned again! nor was any one, even in her own house, acquainted with her benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No one, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P:
Alas, no!—not even her husband; and by this means villainy has succeeded, in transforming a benignant angel, into a daemon of darkness. This man—oh, to what hu∣miliation does not poverty subject human nature!—came to us,
and with insidious promises and persuasions, endeavored to pur∣chase our assistance to his base designs upon her virtue—We spurned his proposals with indignation; but he is no half villain: and last night, as she was administering her usual consolation to our sufferings, he again entered our lodging, and solicited a pri∣vate interview with our guest, on pretence of some important business that concerned her husband. This, after some hesita∣tion, she granted. I know not the whole of what passed between them: but a probable conjecture may be formed from this letter which had dropped from the hands of the unfortunate woman, as she fell senseless upon the floor.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.

LETTER.P: From the State Prison.— Dissembling woman! enjoy thy triumph!—thou art free! thou may'st now, without restraint, revel in the Prince's arms!—laugh at me, if you please; I know, myself, that my rage is impotent. I know that I cannot interrupt thy volup∣tuous hours. I am here in chains, and powerless to revenge my wrongs!—yes, in chains through thee!—such is the reward of my faithful love!—Yet, hope not that I can be blinded by the flimsy pretence, on which I am imprisoned—I know well the true reason of my being here—with my own eyes I beheld you steal into the house of wantonness, thanks to the friend who enabled me to detect your falshood!—I am fully sensible, that on earth I cannot hope for redress, that you will secure my perpetual detention in this confinement, while you dishonor my name with impunity—yet tremble at the vengeance that awaits you, when the righteous God shall have freed me by death from these ignominous chains, and have summoned you from the arms of voluptuousness into the cold bosom of the grave!

SP.STAGE: (Smith having read the letter, seizes Allbrand eagerly)
SP.P: Ha! fiend!—this is thy work!—confess it!—Oh, what daggers dost thou not plunge into the hearts of the unfortunate!

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: Sir, you forget yourself!—of what concern can Morland's domestic quarrels be to me?—it is well known, that his wife was formerly in a certain predicament with the Prince— this he has perhaps now first discovered—perhaps he supposes that the connection still continues—for my part, I neither do, nor will, know any thing of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: He himself sought to obtain her favours—and would have influenced our poverty to promote his suit. A pen∣sion for my husband was the promised reward of our infamy:— but failing in his attempt, his mean soul was resolved on ven∣geance.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I am astonished past expression, at all that I see and hear!—Tell me, sincerely, Madam—has Morland ever had any intercourse with your husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: He never even saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: How is this? My secretary informed me, that suspicious meetings were held at your house, in which Morland was principally concerned.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P: I may have been deceived by my informer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Suspicious meetings at our house!—Oh, my Lord! my husband's limbs indeed are crippled, but his heart is sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: I have been imposed upon most shamefully!— What a man have I taken into my confidence!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My part is over, your's is now to come, my Lord Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Prunk, are the guards still in the anti-chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: They are, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Consign the villain into their custody.

SP.SPEAKER: Allbrand.
SP.P:
I have so firm a reliance upon your Excellency's justice, that I do not fear being condemned without sufficient proof of guilt. Nothing has hitherto appeared against me but
empty words—I have only been talked down: yet I doubt not of my innocence triumphing at last over such malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Hypocrite to the end!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: May I request permission of your Excellency to hasten instantly, and inform Mr. Morland, whose freedom you have pronounced as a citizen, of what alone can render his enlargement acceptable—the innocence of his beloved wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: You are right, Madam; and allow me to be your companion; my arm shall support you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Joy will be my sufficient support.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV3.STAGE: —As they are going, the door is opened, and EMI∣LIA rushes in, followed by CAPTAIN ELLFIELD.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (throwing herself at the Minister's feet) Justice, oh Count! justice for my guiltless husband! Compassion for his disconsolate wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Rise, Madam! (reaches her a chair) Recover yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: First pronounce Morland's acquital! Oh! this mis∣ery is insupportable! Awakened from a swoon, I learnt that a noble-minded woman was gone to procure my husband's enlarge∣ment: but she did not return: my impatience could not be re∣strained: anguish lent me wings, and I flew hither!—Oh! I can no more!

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Be composed, Madam. Mr. Morland's acquital is already pronounced—we expect him here, every moment— I am convinced both of his and your innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: My husband at liberty!—my honour vindicated? Great God! (She takes the Minister's hand, and presses it si∣lently to her heart)

SP.SPEAKER: Prunk.
SP.P: (entering) Your Excellency's carriage is retur∣ned.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: With my welcome guest! Hasten to conduct him in. (to Emilia) It is Mr. Morland, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: Morland! (she rushes into his arms, he turns away, she sinks almost fainting into the arms of Smit and Jenny)

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (looking at her with constrained coldness and con∣tempt) Why am I brought hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Unfortunate, misguided man! Oh, cast from thee the poison of unjust suspicion—thy Emilia is innocent—lis∣ten to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Who are you, Madam? I know you not! by what means can you be concerned in our fate?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I owe my life to Mrs. Morland.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland,
SP.P: Still I do not understand you, speak more plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: I lay upon my death-bed, she visited me, ad∣ministered to my wants, sacrificed whole nights to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Whole nights!—Oh! repeat that again!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Yes, whole nights—Believe me, your suspi∣cions have fallen upon a benevolent angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But it was to meet the Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: He never entered our garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Yet I saw a man receive Emilia at your door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: It was my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: But my imprisonment—

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: Was the work of villainy.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: I know it was of Emilia's villainy.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: No, of my Secretary's—of Allbrand's.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Of Allbrand's! of my bosom friend's—impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Most true! he loved your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Oh, horrible! but how know you that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: Would that I were not compelled to repeat it once more! he would have purchased our assistance to his base designs!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And this Emilia concealed from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Through an unfortunate forbearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: Have I not repeatedly assured you of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: And was this his motive for persuading me to escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Most assuredly! he wished at any rate to get the husband out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: For this did he persuade me to write her such a letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Ellfield.
SP.P: A letter that deprived her of her senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Minister.
SP.P: We have all been deceived by a villain, who now expiates his crimes in a dungeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: Great God! What have I done? (he throws himself at Emilia's feet) Pardon injured innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: Emilia.
SP.P: (bending over him) Yes, I am indeed, innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Morland.
SP.P: (rising and clasping her in his arms) My wife! my wife! (Emilia hides her face in his bosom—a long pause)

SP.SPEAKER: Jenny.
SP.P: (giving her hand to Smith) Edward, I am yours.
